notes.note_text:
Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that she is still finding it hard to understand child’s words if she is not looking at him. She notices he leaves off “end sounds” in words (e.g., “ca” for “cat”). No major changes since initial visit.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned to the therapy room with minimal hesitation, holding mom’s hand. Once seated, he engaged well with preferred toys (cars, farm animals). Attention to structured tasks was fair; he worked in short bursts of 3–4 minutes with frequent play breaks.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, t, m/)
- Targeted simple CVC words in imitation (e.g., “cup, cap, cat, map, mop, mat”).
- Child often omitted final consonants or produced a prolonged vowel (e.g., “cu” for “cup”).
- With maximal verbal cueing (“use your quiet ending sound”), visual cues (pointing to mouth), and segmentation (cu—p), he produced a few accurate final consonants, but these were inconsistent and not yet self-initiated.

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and syllables
- Practiced /k/ in isolation using “back sound” cues and mirror.
- Child could approximate the /k/ sound in isolation with simultaneous models and tongue-back cue but frequently substituted /t/ when attempting at the syllable level (e.g., “kuh” → “tuh”).
- Accuracy best in simultaneous production; reduced accuracy when imitating after a delay.

3. Initial /f/ in isolation
- Introduced “lip-bite, quiet air” cue for /f/.
- Child was interested in watching the SLP’s mouth and attempted /f/ in isolation several times.
- Productions were mostly approximations (/h/ or /p/ substitutions). Occasional clear /f/ occurred with hand-on-chin tactile cue and slowed rate, but not yet consistent.

4. Functional word attempts in play
- Encouraged use of single words to request (e.g., “more, go, up, open”).
- Child preferred pointing/gesturing and often used single-word approximations that were difficult to understand.
- With direct models and immediate imitation, he was able to repeat a small set of functional words (e.g., “go, up, in”) with variable clarity.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue targeting final consonants at the imitated word level with high support.
- Maintain focus on establishing more consistent /k/ and /f/ in isolation before expanding.
- Home practice: caregiver to model and emphasize “end sounds” in simple words (e.g., cat, cup, map) during daily routines, praising any attempts at full words rather than correcting heavily.
- Next session: re-check final consonants and initial /k/; consider adding simple CV and CVC syllable drills if attention allows.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother noted that child is starting to copy some words from his favorite TV show but they are often “mumbled.” She has not noticed major changes in clarity at home yet.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child separated from mom with some reassurance and quickly engaged with a car ramp toy. He was generally cooperative, though he needed gentle redirection when he became silly (giggling and making sound effects instead of target sounds). Able to attend to adult-directed tasks for slightly longer stretches today.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, t, m/)
- Revisited same CVC targets in imitation (e.g., “cup, cap, cat, map, mat, mop”).
- Compared to last week, child showed emerging accuracy: more frequent attempts to close the word with a consonant, though often distorted or substituted (e.g., “cub” for “cup”).
- With segmented modeling (e.g., “cu—P”) and moderate verbal cueing, he produced clearer final consonants on several trials. Accuracy is still inconsistent but there were more recognizable final consonants than at the previous session.

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued “back sound” practice with mirror and tactile cue to the throat.
- Child produced /k/ in isolation with improved consistency when imitating the SLP’s model.
- Began trialing simple CV syllables (e.g., “ka, koo”). Many productions remained /t/-like, but there were a few clearer /k/ syllables when given slow modeling and repetition. Still relies on imitation and visual cues.

3. Initial /f/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Used “bite your lip, blow” cue with visual demonstration.
- Child showed more frequent attempts at /f/ today and appeared to enjoy blowing air.
- A small number of productions were clearly /f/, especially in isolation. When paired with a vowel (e.g., “foo, fah”), accuracy decreased and /h/ substitutions reappeared. Continued need for direct modeling and reminders.

4. Functional requesting words in play
- Practiced imitating functional words in play (e.g., “go, up, open, more”) to operate toys.
- Child imitated a few words with slightly clearer articulation than last session and occasionally attempted them spontaneously (e.g., “go” while pushing the car).
- Speech remained difficult to understand without context, but there were more attempts to use words instead of gestures alone.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue at current hierarchy level; skills are beginning to emerge but not yet consistent.
- Maintain emphasis on CVC final consonants and initial /k/ and /f/ in structured imitation.
- Home practice: caregiver to play simple “go/stop” games, encouraging child to say “go” and praising any attempts; continue to gently emphasize end sounds.
- Next session: consider adding a few new CVC words for variety while staying at the same level.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother shared that child is starting to say “cat” and “cup” more clearly at home at times, though it is not consistent. She feels she can understand him slightly better when he is calm and speaking slowly.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child entered the room independently and appeared comfortable with the routine. Good participation in turn-taking games. Attention was improved; he was able to remain in adult-directed tasks for 5–6 minutes with brief play breaks.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, t, m/)
- Targeted a mix of familiar and new CVC words (e.g., “cup, cat, map, mat, hat, hot”) at the imitated word level.
- Notable improvement in consistency: with moderate verbal and visual cues, child frequently marked the final consonant, though some were still imprecise.
- Began to reduce cueing on familiar items; on a small set of practiced words, he sometimes produced the final consonant after just a model without segmentation.

2. Initial /k/ in CV and CVC syllables
- Continued work on /k/ using mirror and “tongue back” cue.
- Child produced /k/ in isolation with relatively good reliability during this session.
- Transitioned to CV syllables and a few simple CVC words (e.g., “key, car, cow”). There was moderate progress; he produced clearer /k/ on several imitated words, though he still frequently substituted /t/ without cues.
- Required verbal reminders (“back sound”) and slow rate to maintain accuracy.

3. Initial /f/ in isolation and simple words
- Practiced /f/ in isolation, CV syllables, and a small set of simple words (e.g., “fun, feet”).
- Child showed emerging ability to produce a recognizable /f/ at the beginning of words when given a clear model and visual cue.
- He occasionally reverted to /p/ or /h/, but the number of accurate productions increased relative to previous session.

4. Functional words and short phrases
- Encouraged child to use words to request and comment (e.g., “more car,” “my turn”).
- Child imitated several 2-word combinations with varying clarity; consonants were often reduced but vowels helped make his intentions clearer.
- No independent phrase-level speech yet in the therapy room, but he was more willing to attempt imitations.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to build consistency at the imitated CVC level for final consonants; consider trialing simple carrier phrases (e.g., “I see __”) for easier words if accuracy remains stable.
- Maintain work on initial /k/ and /f/ in words; may start to probe these sounds in short, highly familiar phrases later in the block.
- Home practice: caregiver to use picture cards or objects for 3–4 target words (e.g., “cat, cup, map”) and encourage slow, clear repetition, praising any attempts at end sounds.
- Next session: re-assess readiness for short phrases using high-probability CVC words.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that family members have commented that child is “a bit easier to understand,” especially for words he practices often. She notices he sometimes corrects himself when she repeats a word back with the end sound.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned smoothly and eagerly chose a board game. He demonstrated good turn-taking and responded well to praise. Attention and participation were strong; he tolerated slightly longer structured tasks without needing as many breaks.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, t, m, n/)
- Continued practice of familiar CVC words and introduced a few new ones (e.g., “pan, man, ten”).
- Accuracy at the imitated word level improved; child often produced the final consonant with only a simple verbal model and light visual cue.
- For a core set of words (e.g., “cup, cat, map”), he produced the final consonant more independently, sometimes without explicit prompting during play.
- Trialed short carrier phrases (e.g., “I see cat,” “my cup”) with these high-probability words. In phrases, he occasionally dropped the final consonant, but there were several successful productions when cued to “keep the end sound.”

2. Initial /k/ in words and short phrases
- Practiced /k/ in initial position in a set of words (e.g., “key, car, cow, coat”).
- Child demonstrated more consistent /k/ productions in imitation, needing fewer reminders to move his tongue back.
- Briefly trialed simple phrases (e.g., “my car, go car”) using picture support. At phrase level, accuracy decreased but he attempted the /k/ in many trials and responded to verbal reminders.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Continued work on /f/ with picture cards (“fish, fan, foot, fun”).
- Child showed moderate progress: clearer /f/ productions were heard more frequently at the word level with a model.
- He still required visual cueing (lip-bite gesture) but needed less repetition than in previous sessions.

4. Functional 2-word combinations
- Targeted functional phrases such as “more please,” “my turn,” “go car.”
- Child imitated several of these with variable clarity; consonants were sometimes omitted, but his willingness to attempt longer utterances increased.
- Some spontaneous single words were noted during play (e.g., “mine,” “up”).

Plan/recommendations:
- Given the moderate, meaningful gains in final consonant production, continue to build consistency at the word level and gradually increase phrase practice for the easiest words.
- Maintain focus on initial /k/ and /f/ at the imitated word level, with occasional phrase probes.
- Home practice: encourage simple phrases using practiced CVC words (e.g., “my cat,” “big cup”) while modeling clear end sounds; keep practice playful and brief.
- Next session: monitor carryover of final consonants in short phrases; adjust hierarchy depending on stability.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother stated that child continues to say “cat” and “cup” clearly in some situations, but in fast speech he still drops the end sounds. She feels his “car” word is much clearer now.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child entered willingly and quickly joined a pretend play activity with animals. He was cooperative overall, though needed occasional reminders to sit upright and face the pictures. Mild silliness at times but easily redirected.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words; phrase level probes)
- Practiced familiar CVC words (e.g., “cup, cat, map, man, pan, hat”).
- Accuracy at the imitated word level remained generally good with light verbal cues. Child continued to demonstrate clearer final consonants on these familiar targets.
- Phrases such as “my cat,” “big cup,” and “see pan” were probed again. Child produced some accurate final consonants within these short phrases, though he was less consistent than at the single-word level.
- Slight improvement in his ability to self-correct when the SLP modeled the phrase with emphasis on the end sound.

2. Initial /k/ in words and short phrases
- Continued practice with “key, car, cow, coat, cat.”
- Child maintained relatively good /k/ production in imitation. He required intermittent reminders to use his “back sound,” but fewer repetitions were needed.
- In simple phrases (“my car,” “go car”), he sometimes substituted /t/ but also had several accurate attempts, indicating gradual consolidation.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Revisited “fish, fan, foot, fun” at the imitated word level.
- Child showed emerging improvement: more consistent /f/ at the beginning of words when given a model and visual cue.
- Occasional /p/ substitutions persisted but appeared less frequent than before.

4. Functional phrases in play
- Used play routines to elicit 2–3 word requests (e.g., “more bubbles,” “open door,” “my turn”).
- Child imitated multiple short phrases; speech remained somewhat reduced in consonant detail, but there were more attempts to include final sounds in familiar words.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to support final consonant production at both single-word and short-phrase levels, focusing on stability rather than rapid advancement.
- Maintain current targets for /k/ and /f/ at the imitated word level with periodic phrase probes.
- Home practice: encourage child to use “my ___” phrases with favorite toys (e.g., “my car, my cup”), and model clear final sounds; praise attempts rather than perfection.
- Next session: re-check phrase-level consistency; consider adding another final consonant (e.g., /n/) more systematically if accuracy remains steady.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that child is using more words in general and is starting to put two words together more often at home (e.g., “my car,” “more juice”). She still notices dropped end sounds but feels overall speech is “a bit clearer” than before.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned easily and appeared excited to show the SLP his toy car from home. He maintained attention fairly well, participated in turn-taking games, and responded positively to verbal praise and token rewards.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Continued practice with familiar CVC words plus some additional /n/ final words (e.g., “pan, man, sun”).
- At the imitated word level, child generally marked the final consonant on known words with minimal prompting.
- In short phrases (e.g., “my cat,” “big pan,” “see sun”), accuracy of final consonants showed gradual improvement, though still not fully consistent.
- Some emerging self-correction when the SLP repeated his phrase with emphasis on the final sound.

2. Initial /k/ in words and short phrases
- Targeted “key, car, cow, coat, cat” again, plus “cup” for /k/ + final consonant.
- Child’s /k/ productions remained fairly strong in imitation; he needed only occasional cues.
- In simple phrases (“my car,” “big car,” “go cow”), he produced /k/ correctly in many attempts, though there were still intermittent /t/ substitutions.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Practiced “fish, fan, foot, fun” and added “four, food.”
- Child produced more consistent /f/ in initial position with models and visual cueing, indicating a small but steady improvement.
- He still occasionally reverted to /p/, especially when speaking more quickly or in play.

4. Functional 2–3 word phrases
- Used play routines and picture scenes to elicit phrases such as “more bubbles,” “open door,” “big car,” “my turn.”
- Child imitated several 2–3 word phrases and initiated some 2-word combinations spontaneously (e.g., “my car,” “more bubbles”).
- Consonant accuracy within these phrases was variable, but phrase length and willingness to talk are increasing.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue consolidating skills at current levels; child is showing small, steady gains but still benefits from consistent modeling and cueing.
- Maintain targets for final consonants, /k/, and /f/ at word and early phrase levels.
- Home practice: encourage short phrases using picture books (e.g., “big cat,” “red car”), emphasizing end sounds and initial /k/ and /f/ when possible.
- Next session: monitor stability; no major changes to hierarchy planned unless accuracy noticeably increases.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother stated that child’s speech this week seemed similar to last week. He continues to use more 2-word combinations but still drops many end sounds, especially when excited.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned without difficulty and quickly engaged with a puzzle activity. Participation was good, though he required a few reminders to wait for his turn before naming pictures. Overall regulation and cooperation were similar to prior session.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Revisited familiar CVC words (“cup, cat, map, man, pan, sun, hat”).
- At the imitated word level, child continued to produce final consonants on many known targets with minimal prompts, similar to last week.
- In short phrases (“my cat,” “see sun,” “big cup”), accuracy remained variable but generally comparable to previous session. He occasionally self-corrected when the SLP highlighted the final consonant.

2. Initial /k/ in words and phrases
- Practiced “key, car, cow, coat, cup, cat” and simple phrases (“my car,” “go cow,” “big cup”).
- /k/ production in initial position remained stable with intermittent cueing. Performance in phrases looked similar to last session, with a mix of correct /k/ and occasional /t/ substitutions.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Continued work on “fish, fan, foot, fun, four, food.”
- Child maintained similar accuracy to last week. He produced recognizable /f/ sounds in many imitated words with visual cueing, but consistency did not noticeably increase.

4. Functional phrases in play
- Encouraged 2–3 word requests and comments (e.g., “more blocks,” “open box,” “my turn”).
- Child imitated multiple phrases and initiated some 2-word combinations spontaneously. Overall phrase length and use were stable compared to last week.

Plan/recommendations:
- Skills appear to be consolidating at the current level. Continue reinforcing final consonants and initial /k/ and /f/ in familiar words and short phrases.
- Home practice: mother to keep modeling and gently emphasizing end sounds and /k/ and /f/ words during daily routines, praising efforts rather than accuracy.
- Next session: maintain same targets; consider adding a new game or activity to keep practice motivating while staying at this level.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother noted no major changes this week. She feels some days he sounds clearer than others, especially when he is not tired. She continues to work on “my car” and “my cup” at home.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child came into the room happily and chose a board game. He remained engaged for most of the session with brief movement breaks. Behavior and attention were consistent with previous sessions.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Practiced the established CVC set and short phrases (“my cat,” “big cup,” “see sun”).
- At the imitated word level, final consonant marking was similar to last week—often present on familiar words with light cues.
- In short phrases, he continued to show mixed accuracy, with some correct final consonants and some omissions. No notable jump in performance compared to prior session.

2. Initial /k/ in words and phrases
- Targeted “key, car, cow, coat, cup, cat” and phrases (“my car,” “go car,” “big cow”).
- /k/ production remained stable. Child needed occasional reminders to use his “back sound,” particularly in phrases, but overall performance was comparable to last week.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Continued with “fish, fan, foot, fun, four, food” at the imitated word level.
- Accuracy of /f/ remained similar to the previous session, with recognizable /f/ in many trials when visual cues were used.

4. Functional phrases
- Used play-based activities to elicit 2–3 word phrases (e.g., “more bubbles,” “open box,” “my turn”).
- Child’s phrase length and frequency of use were consistent with last week. Intelligibility varied but was supported by context.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue reinforcing current targets; skills appear stable and are likely consolidating before next step up the hierarchy.
- Home practice: maintain daily practice with a small set of words and phrases, keeping sessions short and positive.
- Next session: re-assess for any spontaneous improvements that might support increasing phrase-level demands for selected high-accuracy words.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that child had a “regular week” with speech—no big changes noted. She shared that he is starting preschool visits soon and she is hoping his speech will keep improving.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned easily and appeared in good spirits. He engaged with a picture lotto game and participated in structured tasks with support. Overall behavior and attention were very similar to prior sessions.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Revisited familiar CVC words and short phrases (“my cat,” “big cup,” “see sun,” “my pan”).
- At the imitated word level, child continued to mark final consonants on many known words with light prompts; performance was comparable to previous weeks.
- Phrase-level accuracy remained variable but generally stable, with some accurate final consonants and some omissions.

2. Initial /k/ in words and phrases
- Practiced “key, car, cow, coat, cup, cat” in single words and in simple phrases (“my car,” “go car,” “big cat”).
- /k/ production remained steady. Child occasionally needed a reminder to use his “back sound,” particularly when he was excited or speaking quickly.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Continued “fish, fan, foot, fun, four, food” at the imitated word level.
- Accuracy of /f/ was similar to last week. He produced recognizable /f/ in many attempts with visual cueing.

4. Functional 2–3 word phrases
- Encouraged use of short phrases for requests and comments (e.g., “more bubbles,” “open door,” “my turn”).
- Child used several imitated and some spontaneous 2-word phrases during play. Intelligibility and structure were similar to prior sessions.

Plan/recommendations:
- Maintain current therapy focus; skills appear stable with ongoing need for repetition and practice.
- Home practice: continue using picture books and daily routines to model and practice target words and short phrases, emphasizing clear end sounds.
- Next session: continue with same level of difficulty while monitoring for any spontaneous increases in accuracy or independence.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother shared that child has started his preschool visits and teachers have mentioned that they can understand him “some of the time,” especially when context is clear. She has not noticed major changes in the last week.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child entered happily and talked briefly about “school” with single-word and 2-word approximations. He participated well in game-based tasks and required only occasional redirection when he became a bit silly. Attention and engagement remained similar to recent sessions.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Practiced established CVC targets and phrases (“my cat,” “big cup,” “see sun,” “my pan”).
- Child’s final consonant marking at the word level remained consistent with prior weeks, with many accurate productions when given a model.
- In short phrases, he continued to show mixed accuracy, with both correct and omitted final consonants. Performance was stable overall.

2. Initial /k/ in words and phrases
- Targeted “key, car, cow, coat, cup, cat” in single words and phrases (“my car,” “go car,” “big cat,” “my cup”).
- /k/ remained generally accurate in imitated single words with occasional cues. In phrases, he produced /k/ in many attempts but sometimes reverted to /t/ when excited.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Continued “fish, fan, foot, fun, four, food.”
- /f/ productions were similar in quality and consistency to last week. He still benefited from visual cues but produced multiple clear /f/ sounds in imitation.

4. Functional phrases
- Used play scenarios to elicit phrases like “more cars,” “open door,” “my turn,” “big truck.”
- Child produced a range of imitated 2–3 word phrases and a few spontaneous 2-word combinations. Consonant accuracy within phrases remained variable, with overall performance consistent with recent sessions.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue at the current level; skills appear to be consolidating, particularly in familiar words.
- Home practice: parents to keep highlighting end sounds and initial /k/ and /f/ in everyday words (e.g., car, cup, fish, foot), using slow, clear models.
- Next session: maintain current targets; consider informal probe of a new sound or context if child shows signs of increased stability.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that child had a cold this week, so he was a bit quieter at home. She did not notice any significant change in his speech clarity.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child appeared slightly tired but was cooperative. He preferred quieter table-top games and responded well to breaks between tasks. Participation and attention were adequate and similar to prior sessions, given his mild illness.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Revisited familiar CVC words and phrases (“my cat,” “big cup,” “see sun,” “my pan”).
- At the imitated word level, final consonant production remained stable, with many accurate attempts on known words when modeled.
- Phrase-level performance was comparable to recent sessions, with some correct final consonants and some omissions. No marked changes observed.

2. Initial /k/ in words and phrases
- Practiced “key, car, cow, coat, cup, cat” in words and short phrases (“my car,” “big cat,” “go car”).
- /k/ accuracy in initial position remained similar to previous weeks. He produced several correct /k/ sounds in imitation and some within phrases, with intermittent /t/ substitutions.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Continued “fish, fan, foot, fun, four, food” at imitated word level.
- /f/ production quality and consistency were comparable to last session. Visual cues continued to support success.

4. Functional phrases
- Encouraged 2–3 word phrases in simple play routines (e.g., “more bubbles,” “open box,” “my turn,” “big truck”).
- Child produced several imitated phrases and some spontaneous 2-word combinations, similar to previous sessions.

Plan/recommendations:
- Maintain current therapy focus; given recent illness and stable performance, no changes to hierarchy this week.
- Home practice: continue brief, positive practice with target words and phrases, especially when child is feeling better.
- Next session: reassess after recovery from cold; adjust targets if any spontaneous improvement is observed.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother shared that child is feeling better this week. She continues to notice that familiar words like “car” and “cat” sound clearer, but overall speech is still sometimes hard to understand in longer sentences.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child came in cheerful and energetic. He participated in both table-top and floor-based activities and responded well to structured turn-taking. Attention and cooperation were in line with his baseline.

Goals and therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Practiced familiar CVC words and short phrases (“my cat,” “big cup,” “see sun,” “my pan”).
- Final consonant marking at the imitated word level remained stable, with many accurate productions on known targets and occasional omissions on newer or less familiar items.
- Phrase-level accuracy was similar to recent sessions, with a mix of correct and omitted final consonants and some emerging self-corrections when modeled.

2. Initial /k/ in words and phrases
- Continued with “key, car, cow, coat, cup, cat” and phrases (“my car,” “go car,” “big cat,” “my cup”).
- /k/ remained generally accurate in imitation and variable in phrases, mirroring prior performance. Occasional /t/ substitutions persisted.

3. Initial /f/ in words
- Practiced “fish, fan, foot, fun, four, food” in imitation.
- /f/ productions were consistent with previous weeks, with clear /f/ in many attempts when supported by visual cues.

4. Functional phrases and emerging sentences
- Used picture scenes to elicit short phrases and early sentences (e.g., “the cat is big,” “I see car”).
- Child produced several 2–3 word imitated phrases. When longer models were given, he tended to reduce them to shorter phrases. Consonant accuracy within these utterances remained variable, consistent with his current level.

Plan/recommendations:
- Skills are stable at the current level. Recommend continued focus on consolidating final consonants and initial /k/ and /f/ in both single words and short phrases before further increasing complexity.
- Home practice: continue modeling clear end sounds and target consonants within short, functional phrases (e.g., “my cat,” “big fish,” “see car”) during daily routines.
- Next steps: if continuing in a new block, consider periodic probes of additional sounds or positions while maintaining core targets to support generalization.

Parent report:
- Caregiver (mom) shared that she is mostly concerned about others not understanding child's speech, especially with longer words and when talking fast. No major changes reported since initial evaluation. Child starting to ask more questions at home and is very talkative.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned with some hesitation but joined the session with encouragement. Once in the room, she was curious and talkative. Attention to structured tasks was fair; she preferred play-based activities and needed occasional redirection from toys back to speech targets.

Goals / session targets:
1. Initial /s/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Practiced /s/ in isolation using "snake sound" cues and mirror. Able to hold /s/ briefly with clinician model, but productions were often too short or turned into /t/ or /sh/.
- At the CV syllable level (e.g., "see, soo, sah"), she imitated several approximations, but accuracy was inconsistent and required frequent verbal and visual cues.
- At simple word level (e.g., "sun, soup, sock"), she was often substituting /t/ or /sh/ and needed maximal modeling and reminders to keep tongue behind teeth.

2. Final /t/ at word level (imitation)
- Target words included "hat, cat, boat, feet." She often omitted the final sound or added a vowel (e.g., "ha" for "hat," "fee" for "feet").
- With simultaneous production and hand-tapping cues for the final sound, she was able to mark /t/ in some words, but consistency was low.

3. Initial /k/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Child tended to front /k/ to /t/ (e.g., "tar" for "car"). Practiced tongue-back placement using a "cough" and "back sound" trick.
- In isolation, a few clear /k/ productions emerged with maximal tactile/visual cues.
- At word level ("car, key, cow"), productions were mostly /t/; accurate productions occurred only with heavy support.

4. Functional communication observation
- During play, child used many 2–4 word phrases (e.g., "my turn," "I want that," "go fast") but speech clarity reduced in longer phrases. Intelligibility with familiar listener (clinician) was fair; needed repetition requests.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to focus on establishing consistent productions of /s/, /t/, and /k/ in isolation and simple syllables before moving up the hierarchy.
- Home practice: caregiver encouraged to model slow, clear "snake sound" /s/ during play and to emphasize final sounds in everyday words (e.g., "hat," "cat") using a light tap gesture on the table or child’s hand. Keep practice playful and brief (1–2 minutes, a few times per day).

Parent report:
- Mom reported that child has started trying to copy some of the "snake sound" /s/ practice at home and enjoys making the sound in front of the mirror. No major changes in overall clarity, but mom notices child "trying harder" with certain words like "sun" and "soap."

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child separated easily from caregiver and appeared excited to show "snake sound." Engagement was good, with better tolerance for short structured tasks between play. Some silliness noted when tasks were more challenging, but she responded to gentle redirection.

Goals / session targets:
1. Initial /s/ in isolation, syllables, and words (imitation)
- Marked improvement in ability to sustain /s/ in isolation with visual cue (finger in front of mouth) and mirror. She could hold a clear /s/ for several seconds in multiple trials.
- At CV syllable level ("see, soo, sah, say"), productions were more consistent; occasional distortions but clearer airflow and less backing to /sh/.
- At word level ("sun, soup, sock, soap"), she achieved multiple accurate imitations with verbal reminders to "keep tongue behind teeth." Still required models but needed fewer repetitions to achieve a correct production.

2. Final /t/ at word level (imitation)
- Continued with "hat, cat, boat, feet" plus a few new words. She more consistently marked the final /t/ with simultaneous production and a tapping cue.
- Some spontaneous approximations (e.g., saying "hat" with a clear final sound during a game) were observed, although still inconsistent.

3. Initial /k/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Used "cough" trick and tongue-back placement. Child produced more recognizable /k/ in isolation than last session.
- At CV level ("kee, koo, kah"), she produced a mix of /k/ and /t/ but had more frequent correct trials compared to previous visit.
- At word level ("car, key, cow"), she needed continued maximum verbal/visual cues; still tends to front to /t/, but a few clearer /k/ productions emerged with slow modeling.

4. Functional carryover
- In play, child attempted to use /s/ words from practice (e.g., "sun," "sock") after clinician models. Intelligibility was slightly improved when she slowed down and used practiced words.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue at word level for initial /s/ and final /t/, with gradual introduction of short carrier phrases for most successful /s/ words in upcoming sessions if consistency continues.
- Maintain focus on establishing /k/ with more consistent accuracy in isolation and syllables before advancing.
- Home practice: encourage short /s/ and /t/ word games (e.g., naming pictures, simple matching). Caregiver to continue modeling slow speech and praising "clear sounds."

Therapy goals and observations:
1. Initial /p, b, m/ in CV and CVC syllables (imitation)
- Targeted simple syllables (e.g., “pa, ba, me, bee, pop, mom”) using picture cards and mirror.
- Child imitated CV syllables with these early sounds with high success when given a direct model and visual cue (lip closure). CVC words were less consistent; final consonants frequently omitted (e.g., “po” for “pop”).
- Benefited from slowed rate and simultaneous productions with clinician.

2. Final consonant production in CVC words (p, m, t)
- Practiced words like “cup, cap, cat, map, mop, mat” at the imitated word level.
- Child attempted final consonants in about half of opportunities; many productions were approximations (e.g., “cu_,” “ma_”). Stopping the word and then adding the “tail sound” helped the child notice the final sound, though carryover to full words was limited.

3. Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Child showed fronting of /k/ to /t/ in spontaneous play (e.g., “tar” for “car”).
- Introduced /k/ in isolation using “tongue up and back” cues and mirror. Child was able to produce a backed sound with maximal verbal and visual support in some trials.
- CV syllables (e.g., “koo, kah”) were attempted but often reverted to /t/; this will remain a primary target.

4. Establishing CV and CVC syllable shapes
- Observed spontaneous use of V, CV, and some CVCV (same) patterns in play (e.g., “mama, dada, baby”).
- When cued, child could imitate a variety of CV and CVCV (same) structures; CVC forms were much more difficult, particularly with final consonant closure.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to target early developing sounds (/p, b, m/) in CV and CVC forms, with emphasis on marking final consonants.
- Continue intensive work on /k/ in isolation and CV syllables with visual supports and mirror.
- Provide parent with a short list of CVC words using /p, m, t/ to practice “tail sounds” at home during play (e.g., “map, mop, cat, cap”).
- Next session: re-check final consonant production and /k/ isolation; consider adding simple two-word combinations if attention allows.

Goals / session focus:

- Obtained an informal speech sample during play and picture naming. Noted frequent final consonant deletions (e.g., "ca" for "cat"), reduced consonant blends, and substitutions for /k/ and /g/ (fronting to /t, d/). Intelligibility reduced in connected speech, especially for unfamiliar topics.

- Targeted simple syllable shapes within play (e.g., "moo, baa, baby, puppy"). Child produced many CV and CVCV forms spontaneously but often reduced accuracy on specific consonants. Focus was on encouraging any clear consonant-vowel pattern rather than specific phonemes.

Behaviour/engagement:

Therapy goals and observations:
1. Baseline for initial /s/ at the word level (imitation)
- Target words included: sun, soap, sock, sit, soup.
- Child typically substituted /t/ or /d/ for /s/ in initial position (e.g., “tun” for sun, “doap” for soap).
- With direct imitation and visual cue to “keep your tongue behind your teeth,” child produced an accurate /s/ in about half of attempts; accuracy decreased without a model.

2. Baseline for /s/ blends in initial position (word level imitation)
- Probed words: stop, snow, spoon, star, slide.
- Frequent reduction of blends to single consonants (e.g., “top” for stop, “no” for snow), or distortion of /s/ to a more /sh/‑like sound.
- Even with simultaneous production and slowed rate, child showed limited success in marking both consonants; required maximal verbal and visual cueing.

3. Baseline for final consonants in CVC words
- Probed final /p, t, m, k/ in simple words (e.g., pop, hat, ham, back).
- In spontaneous play, final sounds were often omitted (“ba” for back, “ha” for hat). With imitation, child marked some final consonants but productions were inconsistent.
- When the clinician used tapping or pointing for each sound, child was able to include the final consonant occasionally, but needed repeated models.

4. Syllable structure and early phrases
- Observed CV, CVC, and some CVCV (reduplicated) word shapes during play (e.g., “mama,” “baba,” “puppy”).
- Child used many 2–3 word phrases spontaneously (e.g., “my car,” “more bubbles,” “I want that”), though overall intelligibility was reduced due to sound errors.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Begin structured practice of initial /s/ at the imitated word level, using mirrors and simple visual cues.
- Introduce very simple /s/ blends (e.g., “stop,” “snow”) in imitation only, focusing on awareness that there are “two sounds at the start.”
- Encourage caregiver to model slower, clear speech at home and to repeat the child’s words back with correct sounds (e.g., “tun – yes, sun”).
- Continue to monitor final consonant production in play and consider a specific final consonant goal in upcoming sessions.

Therapy goals and observations:
Goal 1: Establish /k/ in isolation and simple syllables (back sound vs. front sound)
- Targeted /k/ in isolation using mirror, tongue depressor for awareness only (no placement), and visual of "back sound" vs. "front sound."
- Child often substituted /t/ for /k/ in spontaneous play. With direct imitation and models, child achieved a few accurate /k/ productions but required maximal verbal and visual cueing (e.g., "tongue up and back").
- Able to produce /k/ in isolation in approximately 3–4 clear attempts during the session; difficulty carrying over to syllables (e.g., "koo," "kah").

Goal 2: Initial /f/ at syllable and early word level (imitation)
- Introduced /f/ using "quiet lip air" cue and mirror work. Child tended to stop /f/ to /p/ in spontaneous attempts.
- In imitation of simple syllables ("foo, fee, fa"), child produced a few accurate productions but frequently reverted to /p/ or omitted the airflow.
- At word level with strong models ("fish, fun, four"), accuracy was low and required maximal verbal and gestural cueing.

Goal 3: CV/CVC syllable shapes for clarity in play
- Observed inconsistent marking of final consonants in CVC words during play (e.g., "ca_" for "cat," "do_" for "dog").
- Practiced a small set of high-interest CVC words ("dog, cat, hat, pop") in imitation. Child could approximate final consonants when given slowed rate and segmented models but did not yet produce them consistently.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to focus on establishing /k/ and /f/ at the isolation and simple syllable levels next session; maintain strong visual and verbal cueing.
- Encourage parent to model slow, clear productions of key words at home (e.g., "cat," "dog," "cup") without pressuring the child to repeat.
- Plan to gather additional baseline data on final consonant production and consider adding specific final consonant goals once more stable.

Therapy goals and observations:
Goal 1: /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Reviewed /k/ in isolation with visual of "back sound" and mirror. Child produced /k/ in isolation with moderate cues more consistently than last week.
- Introduced CV syllables ("koo, kah, kee"). With imitation and segmented models ("k" + "oo"), child produced several clear CV syllables; accuracy improved when rate was slowed.
- Occasional spontaneous /k/ attempts noted in play (e.g., approximated "car" as "tar" but then tried to correct with clinician's cue). Early self-correction emerging.

Goal 2: Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Practiced /f/ in isolation using "lip bite and blow" cue. Child was able to achieve the correct placement more often today with moderate verbal and visual cues.
- Moved into CV syllables ("fee, foo, fa"). Child approximated several accurate productions when clinician modeled slow airflow and used hand cue for "air." Still inconsistent but improved from previous session.

Goal 3: CVC words with final consonants (imitation)
- Targeted a small set of CVC words ("dog, cat, pop, map") in imitation.
- With segmented models (e.g., "do" + "g"), child was better able to mark final consonants. Accuracy remained variable, but more final consonant attempts were observed compared to last session.
- Child benefited from visual tapping (one tap per sound) to support awareness of the final sound.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue building consistency for /k/ and /f/ at CV syllable and simple word level; maintain use of segmentation and visual cues.
- Encourage parent to use the "slow and stretchy" model at home for target words, praising any attempts rather than only correct productions.
- Plan to introduce a small set of high-frequency /k/ and /f/ words next session if accuracy at the CV level remains similar.

Therapy goals and observations:
Goal 1: /k/ in connected speech
- Used a short story and role-play with toy cars and cups to elicit sentences and brief narratives containing /k/ words.

- Practiced /f/ in sentences and short story contexts ("four fish at the farm," "five frogs are funny").
- Accuracy in imitation remained good, with light cueing needed intermittently.
- During play, child used several /f/ words spontaneously; clarity was comparable to last week.

Goal 3: Final consonants in CVC words—generalization attempts
- Continued focusing on final consonants in a mix of familiar and slightly less familiar CVC words ("cup, bed, dog, map, bus, fish").
- In drill tasks, child marked many final consonants with minimal cues; no substantial change from previous session.
- In spontaneous phrases and short sentences, final consonants were variably present, especially in familiar words, with overall pattern consistent with recent weeks.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue current approach to support consolidation and generalization of /k/, /f/, and final consonants.
- Caregiver encouraged to provide extra support (slower speech, modeling) at times of fatigue or high excitement when clarity decreases.
- Consider introducing a new target (e.g., initial /s/) in the next session while monitoring maintenance of current skills.

Goals / session focus:
1) Establish production of /f/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Introduced /f/ as a “quiet lip sound” with mirror work and visual cueing for upper teeth on lower lip plus airflow.
- Child produced /f/ in isolation accurately in about half of attempts with direct imitation and strong visual cues; often substituted /p/ or omitted airflow.
- In CV syllables ("fee, foo, fa"), accuracy was low and required simultaneous production with clinician; child tended to revert to /p/.

2) Establish production of /s/ in isolation
- Used snake visual and “long windy sound” description, with mirror for tongue position.
- Child could briefly hold an /s/-like airflow with maximal verbal and gestural cues in a few attempts; frequent intrusions of /t/ or /d/ noted.
- Accuracy inconsistent; required hand-over-hand support for jaw stability.

3) Initial exploration of /s/ blends at the auditory level
- Presented minimal pairs in play (e.g., “pin/spin,” “top/stop”) to build awareness; focus on listening, not production.
- Child enjoyed guessing games and could usually point to the picture named by the clinician, though still needed repetition.
- Spontaneous attempts at blends were reduced to single consonants (e.g., “top” for “stop”).

4) Baseline for final consonants (p, t, k, m)
- During play and simple picture naming, child frequently omitted final consonants (e.g., “ka” for “cat,” “boo” for “book”).
- With immediate imitation and a tap cue on the table for the “ending sound,” child occasionally added a final /p/ or /m/ but not consistently.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue weekly therapy focusing on establishing accurate /f/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables, and increasing awareness of final consonants.
- Home practice: caregiver to model slow, clear /f/ and /s/ sounds in a mirror 3–5 minutes daily, praising any attempts, without forcing repetitions.
- Next session: repeat baseline-style probes for /f/, /s/, and final consonants to monitor early change and determine appropriate word-level targets.

- Appeared proud of their speech work and frequently sought feedback.

Goals / session focus:
1) /f/ initial in sentences and conversational practice
- Reviewed /f/ in simple sentences ("I feed the fish," "The food is hot") and then used these in a short role-play activity.
- Child maintained high accuracy for /f/ in imitation and with minimal cueing; carried clear /f/ into semi-structured conversation in many familiar words.
- Occasional /p/ substitutions occurred when speaking quickly, but child was often able to correct with a brief reminder.

2) /s/ initial at word and phrase level
- Practiced a set of /s/ words ("sun, soup, sock, seat, sand") and short phrases ("sun up," "sock on," "see sun") in imitation and with faded models.
- Compared to previous weeks, child showed more consistent accurate /s/ productions with similar or slightly reduced cueing.
- In structured play, child independently used a clearer /s/ in a few target words without being prompted, indicating emerging generalization.

3) /s/ blends at imitated word level and early phrase attempts
- Targeted /st/ and /sp/ blends in a car and space game ("stop, start, space, speed").
- With strong models and gestures, child produced more recognizable clusters than in earlier sessions, though accuracy remained variable.
- Trialed very short phrases ("stop car," "space ship") in imitation; some attempts maintained the cluster, suggesting early readiness to expand.

4) Final consonants /p, m, t/ in imitation and supported phrases
- Practiced CVC words and then embedded them in short, cued phrases (e.g., “big map,” “hot soup”).
- Child produced final consonants more reliably in structured imitation than in prior weeks and was able to carry accurate final sounds into a few short phrases with clear prompting.
- Spontaneous speech still showed frequent omissions, but practice tasks reflected gradual improvement.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to reinforce /f/ at sentence and conversational levels, with focus on maintaining accuracy as utterances become more complex.
- Build on emerging gains for /s/ in words and phrases; gradually increase the variety of /s/ words used in structured play.
- Home practice: caregiver encouraged to practice a small set of /s/ words and phrases daily and to gently prompt child to “use your snake sound” in familiar contexts if child is receptive.
- Next block (if continued): consider updating goals to reflect progress with /f/ and to increase emphasis on /s/ initial, /s/ blends, and final consonant carryover into more spontaneous speech.

Parent report:
- Parent shared that they are most concerned about how hard it is for unfamiliar adults to understand him, especially when he is excited.
- Parent notices that he often leaves off the last sounds in words and that /s/ and /f/ are hard for him.
- No major changes since evaluation; starting preschool in a few months.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Transitioned into the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from parent with verbal reassurance.
- Once engaged with toys, he was cheerful and cooperative. Attention span was fair; he needed occasional redirection back to speech tasks.
- Responded well to visual supports and turn-taking games.

Therapy goals and observations:
1) Establish production of early consonants in isolation (p, b, m, t, d, k, g)
- Probed in play and structured imitation. /p, b, m, t, d/ generally present in simple CV syllables (e.g., "bee," "moo"), but final consonants were frequently omitted in CVC words (e.g., "boo" for "boat").
- /k, g/ were often fronted to /t, d/ in both imitation and spontaneous attempts (e.g., "tar" for "car").
- With direct modeling and gesture cues (tapping throat vs. lips), he could occasionally imitate /k/ in isolation but had difficulty carrying it into syllables.

2) Final consonant production at the imitated word level (CVC words)
- Targeted final /p, m, t/ using picture cards and simple games (e.g., "pop," "map," "cat").
- Frequently omitted final sounds or added a neutral vowel ("puh"). Needed maximal verbal cueing ("keep your sound on") and visual cues (pointing to lips) to mark the final consonant.
- Achieved a small number of clearly marked final consonants with simultaneous production (saying it together with SLP); independent productions were inconsistent.

3) Initial /f/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Introduced /f/ using visual cue of "bite your lip and blow." In isolation, he could approximate /f/ with heavy cueing but often substituted /p/ or produced a prolonged /h/ sound.
- In CV syllables ("foo," "fee"), productions were mostly /p/ or omitted the consonant. Required maximal modeling and repetition.

4) Initial /s/ in isolation
- Attempted /s/ in isolation with mirror and snake visuals. Productions were often /d/ or a lateralized sound; sustained airflow was difficult.
- Tolerated placement cues (smile, teeth together, long air) but needed hand-over-hand support for airflow.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to build consistent production of final consonants in CVC words and explore stimulability for /k, g, f, s/ at the isolation and syllable levels.
- Provide parent with simple home practice ideas for final sounds (e.g., "pop," "map," "hat") using slow, exaggerated models.
- Next session: further assess stimulability for /k/ and /f/, and begin a small set of core CVC words for practice.

Therapy goals and observations:
1) Final consonant production in CVC words (imitated level)
- Revisited final /p, m, t/ with picture cards and a simple board game.
- Compared to last session, he showed a noticeable increase in attempts to mark final consonants and occasionally self-corrected when given a questioning look.
- With direct imitation and visual cues, he produced more accurate final consonants (e.g., clearer /p/ in "pop" and /m/ in "ham"). Still frequently omitted or reduced final consonants in spontaneous play, but accuracy in structured imitation was meaningfully higher.

2) Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Focused on back-of-the-tongue placement using a puppet and "cough" trick.
- Demonstrated improved stimulability: could imitate /k/ in isolation multiple times with moderate verbal and visual cues, versus only rare approximations last week.
- In CV syllables ("koo," "kee"), productions were mixed; about half of attempts were closer to /k/ rather than /t/ when given slowed models and placement reminders.

3) Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued to use "bite your lip and blow" cue. He was more willing to look in the mirror and watch the SLP's mouth.
- Produced clearer /f/ in isolation intermittently with moderate cues. Still tended to default to /p/ in syllables, but there were a few accurate CV productions (e.g., "fee") when slowed down and given extra modeling.
- Emerging accuracy noted; still needs substantial support, but performance improved compared to baseline.

4) Early /s/ work in isolation
- Briefly revisited /s/ in isolation; airflow still challenging, and productions often sounded like /t/ or a distorted fricative.
- Tolerated tactile and visual cues but required maximal support; /s/ remains a longer-term target.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue targeting final consonants in a small core set of CVC words, building consistency at the imitated level.
- Maintain focus on /k/ and /f/ in isolation and CV syllables given increased stimulability; consider moving a few /k/ CV syllables into simple words if accuracy holds.
- Encourage parent to practice 3–5 CVC words daily with slow, clear models and lots of praise for any final sound attempts.

Therapy goals and observations:

- Practiced final /p, m, t/ in a small set of words ("pop, map, hat, cat, ham") using a game format.

2) Initial /k/ at syllable and simple word level (imitation)
- Built from CV syllables to a few early /k/ words ("car, key, cow") using picture supports.
- Accuracy in CV syllables improved; he produced /k/ rather than /t/ in most imitated attempts when given a visual cue (hand at throat) and slowed model.
- At the single-word level, he could imitate "car" and "key" with a recognizable /k/ in many trials, though "cow" remained more challenging. Still needed frequent reminders for back-of-tongue placement, but less physical prompting than before.

3) Initial /f/ in isolation, CV, and early word probes
- Continued with mirror and lip-bite cue. Demonstrated more consistent /f/ in isolation with moderate verbal cueing.
- In CV syllables ("fee," "fo"), accuracy was improved, with several clear productions when paced.
- Briefly probed "fish" and "foot"; he approximated /f/ but often shifted to /p/ at faster rates. Moderate, meaningful progress noted from prior sessions, but not yet ready for phrase-level work.

4) Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV) for overall intelligibility
- Observed in play that he uses a range of CV and CVCV shapes. When excited, tends to reduce CVC to CV or CVCV with omitted finals.
- With clinician modeling and visual tapping of syllables, he was able to approximate 2–3 syllable words ("banana," "dinosaur") with most syllables present, though individual sounds were not always clear.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to solidify final consonants in the current CVC set; if consistency remains, consider adding new words or moving a few into short carrier phrases (e.g., "my cat").
- Maintain focus on /k/ at word level in imitation; expand list slightly as accuracy improves.
- Continue practicing /f/ in CV syllables and a very small number of simple words, keeping expectations at the imitated level.
- Home: encourage slow, clear practice of 5–7 target words, praising any attempts to keep the "end sound."

- Still requires support, but shows good awareness and effort.

4) Overall speech sound profile and intelligibility
- In a brief language sample, he used 2–4 word phrases with a variety of consonants and syllable shapes.
- Persistent patterns included final consonant omissions and substitutions for later-developing sounds. Intelligibility to a less familiar listener remained reduced but improved with context and repetition.

Plan/recommendations:
- Recommend continued speech-language therapy to further strengthen final consonant production and increase independence with /k/ and /f/ at phrase and sentence levels.
- Future blocks may begin to introduce new targets (e.g., /sh/, later /s/) once current goals are more consistently met.
- Home: continue daily practice with a small set of target words in short phrases, emphasizing slow, clear speech and praising his efforts and self-corrections.
- Plan to review progress and next-step goals with parent at upcoming follow-up.

Parent report:
Mom shared that she and Dad notice that speech is still "hard to understand" for unfamiliar listeners. She reported that he often leaves off sounds at the ends of words and says "do" for "go" and "tat" for "cat." No major changes since the evaluation. Family is motivated to work on "clear sounds" and is open to home practice.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned with some hesitation but separated from Mom with reassurance and a visual schedule. He was curious and talkative in play, occasionally becoming silly and needing reminders to use his "practice voice" for target words. Attention to table-top tasks was fair; he benefited from frequent movement breaks and using toys as part of drill play.

Goals/targets this session:
1. Establish production of /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- At baseline, client substituted /t/ for /k/ in all word positions (e.g., "tar" for "car").
- With mirror, tongue-back visuals, and tactile cue to throat, he approximated /k/ in isolation in about half of attempts; many productions were closer to /t/ or omitted. He responded best to a whispered /k/ and to pairing with a big yawn.
- In CV syllables ("koo, kah, kee"), accuracy was low and required maximal modeling and simultaneous production.

2. Establish production of /f/ in isolation and initial position of words
- Client often replaced /f/ with /b/ or omitted it ("ish" for "fish").
- With a strong "bite lip, blow" visual cue, he produced /f/ in isolation fairly consistently when watching in the mirror.
- At the imitated CV level ("fee, foo, fah"), productions were inconsistent; he sometimes used /p/ or a labial stop.

3. Final consonant awareness and production
- In spontaneous play, frequent final consonant deletion noted (e.g., "tea" for "teeth," "do" for "dog").
- Used minimal pairs with picture cards (e.g., "bee" vs. "beep," "bow" vs. "boat"). He could hear the difference when the clinician exaggerated final sounds, but was not yet able to reliably add the final consonant in imitation.

4. Functional communication – clear words for key wants/needs
- Identified a small set of functional words to target for clarity (e.g., "more," "go," "up," "mine").
- Client willingly imitated these with varying clarity; consonants were often simplified, but intent was clear in context.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to build accurate /k/ and /f/ in isolation and CV syllables before moving into word-level practice.
- Encourage Mom to model "bite lip and blow" for /f/ during daily routines (e.g., "food," "fish," "four").
- Provide parent with simple visuals for /k/ ("back sound") and /f/ ("lip-bite sound").
- Next session: re-check /k/ and /f/ in isolation, begin structured word-level practice for whichever sound stabilizes first, and continue monitoring final consonant use in play.

- Practiced /s/ in isolation with a “snake sound” visual. Client could sustain a prolonged /s/ with models, but productions were sometimes distorted or stopped. In CV syllables (e.g., “see,” “soo”), accuracy decreased, with substitutions to /d/ or omission. Required direct imitation and modeling; no spontaneous use noted.

- During play, encouraged two-word phrases that highlighted target sounds (e.g., “big cup,” “my cat,” “see snake”). Client produced several two-word combinations, but target sounds were often reduced or omitted. Focus was on exposure and shaping rather than accuracy.

Encourage parents to model slow, clear speech at home and emphasize final sounds in daily routines (e.g., “cuP,” “caT,” “baTH”) without pressuring for imitation. 1. Final consonants (p, t, m) in CVC words – imitation and emerging spontaneous attempts
- Continued practice with final /p, t, m/ using picture cards and a “feeding the puppet” game. Compared with last session, client produced more consistent final consonants in imitation, especially for /p/ and /m/ (e.g., “cup,” “map,” “mom”). Still occasionally dropped final /t/, but with verbal cueing (“keep your sound at the end”) he was able to add it in a second attempt. A few spontaneous productions with clearer final sounds were observed during play (“up,” “pop”), suggesting early carryover.

2. Initial /k/ vs /t/ – CV and CVC syllables
- Practiced “back sound /k/” in CV (koo, key, kah) and simple CVC words (cup, cat, car). Client showed improved ability to produce /k/ in CV syllables with modeling and a mirror, with fewer /t/ substitutions. In CVC words, accuracy remained variable, but he was more willing to attempt correction when given feedback (e.g., “try your back sound”).

3. Initial /s/ – isolation and CV syllables
- Revisited /s/ in isolation and CV syllables using a “snake puppet” and visual cue for teeth together. Client’s isolated /s/ was more consistent today with less stopping. In CV syllables (see, soo, saa), he was able to approximate /s/ at the beginning of the syllable more frequently with verbal and visual cues, though some productions were still substituted or omitted.

4. Two-word combinations featuring target sounds
- Encouraged phrases such as “my cup,” “see car,” “big sun” during play. Client produced several two-word combinations; target sounds were more audible in imitation than in spontaneous attempts. Still relies on models for clearer productions.

Plan / recommendations:
Maintain current focus on final consonants and initial /k/ and /s/ at the word and syllable level, as skills are beginning to emerge. Provide parents with a short list of practice words for final /p/ and /m/ to use in play (e.g., pop, up, map, nap, mom). Next session will continue to strengthen consistency and begin to probe whether any targets are ready to move toward short carrier phrases in structured tasks.

Parent report:
Mom reported that he is starting to correct himself occasionally, especially on words like “cup” and “pop,” after she models them. She feels some single words are clearer, but sentences are still hard to understand. No new concerns at home or daycare.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was cheerful and eager to show toys. He maintained engagement in table-top tasks for longer stretches and followed simple directions well. Mild silliness at times, but easily redirected with visual supports and choice-making.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, m, k) in CVC words – imitation and early carrier phrases
- Practiced final /p, t, m, k/ in CVC words using a board game and picture cards. Compared with last week, accuracy in imitation increased noticeably, with clearer final consonants on many trials (e.g., “cup, cap, cat, back, mom”). He required fewer repetitions and was able to add missing final sounds when cued. Trialed simple carrier phrases (e.g., “my cup,” “I see cat”) with moderate support; final sounds were sometimes maintained in these short phrases, though consistency decreased compared to single words.

2. Initial /k/ in CV and CVC words – imitation and minimal pairs
- Focused on distinguishing /k/ from /t/ using minimal pairs (e.g., key/tea, car/tar). Client showed improved accuracy for /k/ in initial position in imitation, especially when reminded to use his “back sound.” He could correctly identify which word the clinician said most of the time and made more accurate attempts to match it. Occasional fronting to /t/ still occurred, but he responded to cues to “make it in the back.”

3. Initial /s/ in CV and simple CVC words
- Continued practice with /s/ at the beginning of words in a “snake race” game. Client produced more consistent initial /s/ in CV syllables (see, soo, saa) with visual and verbal cues. In simple CVC words (sun, soup, sock), accuracy was emerging; he sometimes substituted /d/ or omitted the sound, but showed increasing willingness to adjust his productions when prompted.

4. Short carrier phrases with target words
- Used repetitive carrier phrases such as “I want ___,” “my ___,” and “see ___” with target words containing final consonants or initial /k/ and /s/. Client could imitate short phrases with support and occasionally produced them spontaneously in play. Target sounds were clearer in imitation than in independent use, but overall phrase length and willingness to talk were strengths.

Plan / recommendations:
Given the moderate gains in final consonant and initial /k/ production, continue to build consistency at the word level while gradually increasing use in short phrases in structured play. Provide parents with 5–6 practice words for final /p, t, m, k/ and encourage modeling within simple phrases (e.g., “big cup,” “hot cat”). Next session will further trial carrier phrases and monitor readiness to expand to more spontaneous use in play.

Parent report:

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, m, k) in CVC words and short phrases
- Continued work on final consonants in a picture-matching and “shopping” game. Compared with last session, productions were more consistent at the single-word level, especially for /p/ and /m/. Final /t/ and /k/ were improving but still less stable. In short phrases (e.g., “my cup,” “big cat,” “in back”), he was able to maintain the final consonant more often than previously, though accuracy still dropped relative to single words.

2. Initial /k/ in CVC words and simple phrases

In short phrases (“go car,” “my car,” “key please”), he was able to approximate /k/ with moderate verbal cueing. He sometimes self-corrected after hearing the clinician’s model.

- Targeted initial /s/ in words (sun, sock, soup, soap) using a “sorting” activity. Accuracy in imitation was slightly better than last session but remained inconsistent. He occasionally produced a stopped or distorted version of /s/. Visual cues (showing teeth, long air sound) were still needed, and carryover to phrases was not yet targeted.

4. Short carrier phrases to support intelligibility
- Used repetitive phrases (“I want ___,” “see my ___,” “put in ___”) with target words containing final consonants or initial /k/. Plan / recommendations:
Continue strengthening final consonant production and initial /k/ in both single words and short phrases, as gains are building. Maintain initial /s/ at the word level until productions become more consistent before moving to phrases. At home, parents are encouraged to prompt slower speech and model short, clear phrases rather than long sentences. Next session will reinforce these targets and probe for any emerging spontaneous use of final consonants in unstructured play.

Parent report:

Parent report:
Mom shared that she has noticed a “big jump” in how clearly he can say some of his practiced words and phrases, especially ones with /k/ and final /p/ or /m/. She reported that daycare staff also commented that they are understanding him more during routines.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was very engaged and talkative today. He initiated interactions, followed multi-step play routines, and responded well to feedback. He showed clear interest in trying to “fix” his words when given simple cues, indicating increased awareness of his speech.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, m, k) – phrase and simple sentence level, increased independence
- Used a picture-sequencing and storytelling activity to embed CVC words with final consonants into short sentences (e.g., “The cat sits on the mat,” “Mom has a cup,” “Put the map in the bag”). Compared to previous sessions, he demonstrated noticeably higher consistency in producing final /p/ and /m/ and improved accuracy for /t/ and /k/ within these short sentences. He often maintained final consonants without needing direct prompts and occasionally self-corrected when he noticed an omission.

2. Initial /k/ – short sentences and early conversation
- Practiced initial /k/ in short sentences (“The car is fast,” “The cow eats,” “I can kick”) and then in more natural play-based conversation about cars and animals. He produced /k/ accurately in many imitated and some spontaneous sentences with minimal cueing. Fronting errors were less frequent and, when they occurred, he typically responded to a brief reminder (“back sound”) and corrected himself.

3. Initial /s/ – word and early phrase level
- Continued with initial /s/ in words (sun, soup, sock, sand, soap, seat) and expanded phrase-level practice (e.g., “see sun,” “soap on,” “sock on”). Accuracy at the word level was meaningfully better than earlier weeks, with more consistent /s/ productions in imitation and some clearer productions in short phrases with visual and verbal cues. Still requires support but is ready for more regular phrase practice.

4. Functional short sentences – generalization
- Encouraged the client to use short sentences to request, comment, and describe during play (e.g., “I want more,” “My car is stuck,” “Put it in cup”). Intelligibility within these short, familiar sentence frames was noticeably improved, and he seemed proud when others understood him without repetition.

Plan / recommendations:
Given the marked progress, it is appropriate to continue advancing final consonant and initial /k/ targets into short sentences and structured conversational contexts. For /s/, continue to build consistency at the word level while steadily incorporating short phrases. Parents are encouraged to prompt short sentences at home (e.g., “I want ___,” “I see ___”) and reinforce clear final sounds and initial /k/ when they naturally occur. Next sessions will focus on maintaining these gains and expanding to more spontaneous use in play and conversation.

Parent report:
Mom reported that his overall speech clarity continues to feel similar to the last few weeks. She is pleased with how far he has come since starting therapy and would like to keep focusing on tricky sounds like /s/ and some longer sentences. No new concerns were noted.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned easily and was enthusiastic about participating. He remained engaged across the session with only brief need for redirection. He showed good tolerance for practice and enjoyed talking about his interests.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, m, k) – maintenance in sentence and narrative contexts
- Used short stories and picture descriptions to elicit sentences with final consonants (e.g., “The cat sits on the mat,” “Mom has a cup,” “The duck is back in the pond”). His performance was in line with prior weeks: final /p/ and /m/ were consistently present and clear; final /t/ and /k/ were generally accurate in familiar sentences, with occasional omissions in newer or more complex structures. He continued to respond to reminders to slow down and “add the end sound.”

2. Initial /k/ – conversational use and carryover
- Incorporated initial /k/ words into natural conversation and open-ended questions (e.g., “What can the car do?”, “What can we cook?”). He produced /k/ accurately in most spontaneous attempts with minimal cueing, indicating stable carryover. Errors were infrequent and typically occurred when he was speaking quickly or overlapping with the clinician.

3. Initial /s/ – word and short phrase level, ongoing focus
- Practiced initial /s/ in a core set of words and phrases (sun, soap, sit, sock, soup, “see sun,” “sit down,” “soap on”). Accuracy remained variable but showed some correct productions within each activity. He continued to require visual cues (teeth together, long air) and verbal reminders. No major change from the last several sessions, suggesting this remains a developing target.

4. Functional sentences and short narratives – overall intelligibility
- Encouraged him to use short sentences to describe actions and retell simple events (e.g., what happened in the picture story, what he did over the weekend). Intelligibility in these short narratives was noticeably better than at the beginning of the therapy block, though still variable depending on length, rate, and the presence of more challenging sounds like /s/.

Plan / recommendations:
Continue to provide therapy to maintain and further refine final consonant and initial /k/ skills at the sentence and conversational level, and to support ongoing development of initial /s/. Recommend that parents keep modeling clear /s/ in daily routines and practice a small, consistent set of /s/ words and phrases. Future sessions will likely target /s/ more intensively and explore additional sounds or longer utterances as appropriate, while monitoring generalization of existing gains.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported ongoing concerns about speech clarity, especially with unfamiliar listeners. She noted that he often leaves off the ends of words and that /k/ and /g/ are “usually a /t/ or /d/ sound.” No major changes since initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Client transitioned with mild hesitation but separated from caregiver with reassurance. Once in the room, he engaged well in floor play and turn-taking games. Attention was variable; he needed frequent redirection back to speech tasks but responded to visual supports and short activities.

Goals / session targets:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted final consonants at the imitated word level in play (e.g., map, mop, moon, mat, hat). Client frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous productions (e.g., “ma” for “map”) but could add them with direct models and segmenting ("ma-p"). Accuracy in imitation was inconsistent; many productions were approximations (reduced volume, distorted, or very soft final sounds). Required frequent verbal reminders to "keep the sound at the end" and visual cue of pointing to a picture of the tail of a word.

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Practiced /k/ in isolation using a "back sound" cue and mirror. Client could sometimes approximate /k/ after several simultaneous productions with the clinician but often reverted to /t/. In CV syllables (e.g., "koo, kah"), productions were mostly /too, tah/. Needed maximal verbal and gestural cues, as well as tactile cue on throat to feel "quiet back sound." Limited success beyond a few clear approximations.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation
- Introduced /s/ as a "long quiet sound" using snake visuals. Client was able to approximate a prolonged airflow sound in isolation with moderate verbal cueing and modeling. However, productions were often short or had added /t/ onset. Did not yet attempt /s/ in syllables.

4. Early syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Observed in play: consistent CV and CVCV (same) syllable shapes (e.g., "mama," "dada," "baba"). Some CVC words attempted spontaneously but with frequent final consonant deletion.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to target final consonants in high-interest play activities at the imitated word level.
- Maintain focus on establishing /k/ and /s/ in isolation before moving to syllables.
- Home practice: caregiver encouraged to emphasize final sounds in everyday words (e.g., "up," "in," "out") using slow, clear models and positive reinforcement for any attempts at final sounds.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother shared that he has been “trying to copy” how she says words when she reminds him to use his ending sounds, but she still finds him hard to understand in conversation. No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Client entered readily and appeared comfortable with clinician. Participated well in table-top games when they were brief and interactive. Some silliness and sound play, but this was redirected into therapeutic practice.

Goals / session targets:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Continued at imitated word level using picture cards and a fishing game. Compared to last week, client showed clearer marking of final consonants when given a segmented model (e.g., "ma-p"). He produced several words with more distinct final sounds without needing the segmenting cue after initial practice. Omission of final consonants still frequent in spontaneous play, but emerging ability to self-correct when reminded (e.g., added /p/ after clinician’s cue “listen, did you hear the end?”).

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Notable improvement in ability to produce /k/ in isolation with visual support (mirror and tongue-back cue). Client produced multiple accurate /k/ sounds in a row when focused. In CV syllables ("ku, ko, ka"), still frequently fronted to /t/, but there were a few clear /k/ productions with simultaneous models. Needed moderate-to-maximal cues, though fewer repetitions were required compared to previous session.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and early syllables
- Practiced long /s/ in isolation with snake toy. Client produced a more consistent, continuous airflow and could maintain the sound for longer durations. Trialed CV syllables ("see, soo") in imitation; accuracy was variable, with some productions approximating /sh/ or adding a /t/ onset. With verbal cueing to "keep tongue behind teeth and blow," he was able to achieve a few accurate productions.

4. Syllable shape and intelligibility monitoring
- In play-based language, continued to observe frequent final consonant deletion, but increased willingness to repeat words after a model. Caregiver report and in-session behavior suggest slightly increased awareness of speech clarity.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue with final consonants at the imitated CVC word level, with gradual introduction of simple carrier phrases once accuracy is more consistent.
- Maintain /k/ and /s/ practice in isolation and simple CV syllables, with focus on reducing fronting and adding consistency.
