Attention to adult-directed tasks was variable; he preferred self-directed play and needed frequent gentle redirection. Accepted visual schedule and simple choices.

Goals/targets this session:
1) Establish baseline for speech sound production
- During play-based interaction, overall intelligibility to the clinician was reduced in connected speech. Frequent omission of final consonants (e.g., "ki" for "kick," "do" for "dog"), and inconsistent marking of consonant blends ("top" for "stop," "pider" for "spider").
- Syllable shapes observed: strong use of CV and CVCV patterns; CVC and CCVC forms were less consistent.

2) Initial /f/ at isolation and syllable level
- Introduced /f/ as a "quiet lip bite air" sound. In isolation with visual model and mirror, client approximated /f/ in about half of attempts; often substituted /p/ or produced only airflow without lip contact.
- In CV syllables ("foo," "faa"), accuracy was low; productions frequently shifted to /p/ ("poo"). Maximal verbal and visual cues required.

3) Initial /s/ at isolation level
- Client demonstrated awareness of /s/ when modeled, occasionally labeling it as a "snake" sound. In isolation, /s/ often produced as /d/ or lateralized with extra airflow.
- With mirror and slowed modeling, he produced a recognizable /s/ in some attempts, but could not yet maintain consistency. Required maximal verbal cueing and some tactile cueing (finger to sides of mouth) to shape airflow.

4) Final consonant production (general)
- Probed final /p, m, t/ in CVC words ("map," "cat," "cup") in imitation. Client omitted final consonants in most attempts. When provided with segmented modeling and tapping for each sound, he could add a final consonant occasionally but not reliably.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build rapport and establish routine.
- Next session: continue shaping /f/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables; continue probing final consonants.
- Home practice: caregiver encouraged to model slow, clear productions of target words during daily routines (e.g., "feet," "soap," "cup") without pressure for the child to imitate; praise any clear attempts. No formal homework sheet provided today.

Plan / recommendations:

Parent report:

Behaviour/engagement:
- Client transitioned to the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from mother without tears. He warmed up quickly with preferred cars and animal toys. Attention to adult-directed tasks was fair; he needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to speech activities. Participated well with visual supports and short, play-based tasks.

Goals / therapy focus:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words)
- Targeted final /p/ and /t/ in simple CVC words (e.g., “cup, up, hat, hot”) in imitation. Client frequently omitted final consonants (“cu,” “ha”). With simultaneous production and direct modeling, he produced final consonants clearly in about half of opportunities. Required frequent visual cues (pointing to mouth, tapping picture for the “end sound”) and slowed rate.

2. Initial /f/ at syllable and word level
- Practiced /f/ in isolation (“ffff”) and in simple syllables (“fuh, foo”). Client could approximate /f/ with moderate verbal cues to “bite your lip and blow,” but often substituted /p/ or /b/. At the word level (e.g., “fish, four, foot”), accuracy was low; productions were often “pish, bor.” Heavy modeling and mirror work used; client responded well to watching the clinician’s mouth.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Introduced /s/ in isolation using “snake sound” imagery. Client produced a prolonged /s/ sound with air mostly through the center of the tongue in some attempts, but often distorted to /th/ or stopped to /t/. At the syllable level (“see, soo”), accuracy was inconsistent even with maximal cues and models. Used gestural cue (finger in front of mouth like a snake) with some success.

4. Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Observed spontaneous productions in play (e.g., “mama, baby, go car”). Client produced a variety of CV and CVCV (reduplicated) shapes. In imitation tasks with picture cards, he could imitate most CV and CVCV forms, but often simplified CVC to CV.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to target final consonants in high-interest CVC words and build consistency at the imitated word level.
- Continue to establish /f/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables before moving to more complex words.
- Suggested home practice: parent to model and emphasize end sounds in everyday words (e.g., “cup,” “bed”) and practice “snake sound” /s/ in a mirror for short periods during play.

Many words produced with a clear final sound, though sometimes released with an extra vowel (“cup-uh”). Emerging ability to self-correct when provided with a second model.

2. Initial /f/ at syllable and word level
- Practiced /f/ in isolation, CV syllables, and high-interest words (“fish, food, fun”). - During play, encouraged simple two- and three-word phrases (e.g., “more cars,” “big truck”). Client imitated short phrases in many opportunities but often reduced or blurred final consonants. Intelligibility improved slightly when he slowed his rate with clinician modeling.

Parent report:
Mom reported that she and Dad understand most of what he says, but preschool staff have commented that peers have difficulty understanding him, especially in longer sentences. She notices he often leaves off sounds at the ends of words and says “tup” for “cup” or “doap” for “soap.” No concerns with hearing or health this week.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned to the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from Mom without tears. Needed a few minutes of free play to warm up, then responded well to structured turn-taking games. Attention was fair; he stayed with adult-directed activities for short bursts (3–4 minutes) with occasional redirection. Enjoyed cars and animal toys and was generally cheerful.

Goals / session focus:
1) Establish baseline for overall speech sound production
- During play and picture naming, frequent final consonant deletion (e.g., “bee” for “beep,” “boo” for “book”) and cluster reduction were noted. Intelligibility with the clinician was reduced in unfamiliar contexts, though Mom could often interpret his speech.

2) Final /p, t, k/ at word level (imitation)
- Introduced CVC words with final /p, t, k/ using picture cards and a simple board game (e.g., “cup, cat, cake, cap, bike, boat”). Client was able to imitate final consonants inconsistently; often added a vowel (“cup-uh”) or omitted the final sound. Rough estimate: about 40–50% accurate in direct imitation with maximal verbal and visual cues (exaggerated mouth movements, tapping the table for the last sound).

3) Initial /k/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- In isolation, client could approximate /k/ with tongue-back cueing and using a “cough sound” trick, but often fronted to /t/ (“tar” for “car”). At the CV syllable level (e.g., “kee, koo, kah”), productions were mostly /t/ despite simultaneous modeling. Accuracy for clear /k/ in initial position was low; client required maximal cueing and slow pacing.

4) Syllable shape practice (CVCV)
- Practiced simple CVCV patterns (e.g., “mama, puppy, baby”) in play. Client enjoyed repeating these and was more successful with reduplicated syllables (e.g., “mama”) than alternating ones (e.g., “bunny”). Productions were often approximated but generally recognizable.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to target final /p, t, k/ at the imitated word level, focusing on awareness of the “last sound” in words.
- Maintain work on initial /k/ in isolation and simple syllables with heavy visual/tactile support.
- Provide Mom with a short list of final /p/ words (“cup, up, soup”) to model at home during daily routines, emphasizing the last sound without pressuring him to repeat.
- Monitor overall intelligibility and tolerance for structured practice in upcoming sessions.

He produced final /p/ fairly consistently in words like “cup, up, pop,” especially when the SLP tapped for the last sound. Final /k/ remained harder, often fronted to /t/ (“back” → “bat”). 3) CVCV and multisyllabic word practice
- Practiced CVCV words (e.g., “bunny, puppy, teddy”) in a picture book activity. Most syllables were present but some consonants were unclear. With slow modeling and clapping syllables, he was able to imitate 2–3 syllable words like “banana, dinosaur” in a simplified form.

4) Early /s/ awareness (listening)
- Briefly introduced listening discrimination for /s/ vs. no /s/ in simple words using a “sound detective” game (e.g., “sun” vs. “un”). He could usually identify when the SLP used the “snake sound,” though this was not yet targeted for production.

Plan / recommendations:

Mom shared that he has been very talkative at home and is starting to correct himself occasionally without her prompting, especially on words like “cup” and “back.” She still notices that he drops sounds when he is excited.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client arrived energetic but cooperative. He participated well in structured games and responded positively to feedback. He sometimes rushed through words, but accepted reminders to slow down and “use his good sounds.”

Goals / session focus:
1) Final /p, t, k/ at word and short phrase level
- Practiced final consonants in a matching game and short phrases (“my cup, big hat, my book, in back”). He maintained good accuracy for final /p/ and /t/, and final /k/ continued to show clearer productions in familiar words, though not yet fully consistent. Overall, skills were comparable to recent sessions, with evidence of consolidation rather than major change.

2) Initial /k/ at word and two-word level
- Used a play garage set to target /k/ words (“car, key, coat, cookie”) and phrases (“my car, big cookie”). He demonstrated continued ability to produce /k/ correctly in many imitated trials when focused and cued. Occasional /t/ substitutions persisted, especially during more spontaneous play. Cueing demands and accuracy were similar to previous sessions.

3) /s/ in isolation and CV syllables; probe for word-level /s/
- Practiced sustained /s/ and CV syllables with the “snake sound” game. Accuracy in isolation remained good with visual support. A brief probe of simple /s/ initial words (e.g., “sun, soup”) showed emerging but inconsistent productions; he often added a slight “t” or distorted the sound. At this time, /s/ remains best targeted in isolation and syllables.

4) Multisyllabic word imitation (brief)
- Continued brief work on 2–3 syllable words during book reading, with similar performance to prior sessions.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain focus on final consonants and initial /k/ at current levels, continuing to build consistency.
- Keep /s/ primarily at isolation and syllable level, with occasional probes of simple word-level targets to monitor readiness.
- Mom encouraged to note and praise any spontaneous self-corrections and to continue emphasizing slow, clear speech during everyday interactions.

Parent report:
Mom reported that overall clarity feels similar to the last couple of weeks. She hears some very clear words with end sounds, especially when he is calm, but these are not yet consistent in busier situations.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned smoothly and was eager to choose between table-top and floor games. He was attentive and cooperative, though he occasionally became silly toward the end of tasks. Gentle redirection was effective.

Goals / session focus:
1) Final /p, t, k/ at word and short phrase level
- Continued practice of final consonants in structured games and short phrases (“big cup, hot soup, my book, in back”). He maintained strong performance for final /p/ and /t/ with minimal cueing and showed ongoing but still variable accuracy for final /k/. Performance and cueing needs were similar to previous sessions, indicating stable skills at this level.

2) Initial /k/ at word and two-word level
- Used a picture-based board game to elicit /k/ words and phrases. He continued to demonstrate good accuracy in many imitated /k/ words when provided with tongue-back and slow speech cues. Substitutions to /t/ persisted intermittently, particularly when he was speaking quickly or less focused. No major changes from prior sessions were observed.

3) /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Practiced sustained /s/ and CV syllables using a “snake path” visual. He could produce a clear /s/ when cued and maintained it for several seconds. CV syllables showed recognizable /s/ but remained somewhat inconsistent. Skills are consolidating at this level.

4) Brief generalization in play
- During free play, the SLP modeled target words and listened for spontaneous productions. He produced a few approximations with final consonants (e.g., “book”) without direct prompting, similar to what has been heard in recent sessions.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue with current targets and levels to support consolidation and generalization.
- Maintain home practice on final consonants and /k/ in everyday routines, focusing on slow, clear speech.
- Continue /s/ work at isolation and syllable levels, with occasional probes for simple word-level use.

Parent report:

Goals / session focus:

- Used a car track activity to elicit /k/ words (“car, key, coat, cookie”) and phrases (“my car, big cookie”). He produced /k/ correctly in many imitated trials when given visual and verbal cues. Some /t/ substitutions persisted, especially in less familiar words. Overall, cueing needs and accuracy were similar to prior weeks.

Parent report:
- Mother reported ongoing concerns about speech clarity, especially with unfamiliar listeners. She noted that he is "chatty" at home but often leaves off the ends of words and mixes up his /k/ and /t/ sounds. No recent changes in health or hearing.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Client transitioned to the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from mom with verbal reassurance. Once in the room, he warmed up and participated well in play-based tasks. Attention was fair; required several redirections away from preferred toys to structured activities.

Goals/therapy activities:
1. Final consonant production (CV → CVC words)
- Targeted final /p/, /t/, and /m/ at the imitated word level (e.g., "cup, cap, cat, hat, home, ham").
- Client frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous speech ("cu" for "cup"). With direct imitation and visual cueing (touching lips for /p/, tapping chin for final sound), he produced clearer CVC words in about half of opportunities. Final /m/ was easiest; /t/ was often reduced to a softer or omitted sound.

2. Initial /k/ vs /t/ (back vs front sounds)
- Introduced /k/ in isolation using a "back sound" cue (tongue up and back, open mouth). In isolation, he could approximate /k/ intermittently, often defaulting to /t/.
- At the syllable level ("ku, ki, ko"), accuracy was low; most productions were fronted to /t/. Needed maximal verbal models, mirror work, and tactile cues to the throat area to increase awareness of the "back" sound.

3. Early syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Observed and elicited CV and reduplicated CVCV (e.g., "mama, dada, baba") in play. Client produced CV shapes easily and used them spontaneously. For alternating CVCV (e.g., "bunny, kitty"), some consonant changes or vowel distortions were noted, but overall syllable structure was present.

4. Functional words/short phrases in play
- Encouraged use of short 2–3 word phrases (e.g., "my turn," "more bubbles," "go car") with models and imitation. Client imitated several phrases but often reduced them to 1–2 words and unclear final sounds. Intelligibility was better with familiar routines and when context was clear.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue focusing on final consonant production in CVC words and establishing a more consistent /k/ in isolation and simple syllables.
- Suggested parents emphasize final sounds during daily routines (e.g., “cup-p,” “bed-d”) using slow, clear models without pressure to imitate every time.
- Next session: re-check /k/ in isolation, continue CVC with final /p, t, m/, and consider simple minimal pairs if ready.

Parent report:
- Mother reported that he is “trying harder to say the ends of words” after they practiced some of the home words (cup, cap, cat). She has noticed clearer words with family but still frequent omissions with fast or excited speech.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Smooth transition into the room today. Client was curious about new toys and engaged well in structured play. Attention to task improved compared to last week; required fewer prompts to return to activities. Cooperative with mirror work.

Goals/therapy activities:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (p, t, m)
- Practiced final /p, t, m/ at the imitated word level using picture cards and a simple board game.
- Accuracy for final /m/ and /p/ noticeably improved with a model and visual cue (tapping at the end of the word). Client often self-corrected when cued to “listen for the last sound.”
- Final /t/ remained more inconsistent; he sometimes substituted a softer or distorted sound or left it off entirely. However, he produced a few clear final /t/ words (e.g., "hat," "cat") with moderate verbal cueing.

2. Initial /k/ production (isolation → syllables)
- Returned to /k/ in isolation using “cough” and “back sound” cues. Client produced a more distinct /k/ in isolation in about half of trials with strong modeling.
- At the CV syllable level ("ku, ka"), still frequently fronted to /t/, but there were a few clearer /k/ attempts today with maximal support. Able to hear the difference when SLP contrasted /k/ vs /t/ in some minimal pairs.

3. CVCV words and early multisyllabic attempts
- Practiced CVCV words ("bunny, puppy, kitty") in imitation. Most syllables were present, though some consonants were simplified (e.g., "bubby" for "bunny").
- Client showed increased willingness to repeat longer words compared to last session and enjoyed listening and repeating animal names.

4. Functional 2–3 word phrases
- Modeled and elicited short phrases ("more bubbles," "open door," "my car"). Client imitated several with clearer initial sounds; final sounds still often reduced.
- Some spontaneous 2-word combinations observed in play ("my car," "more please"), with mixed intelligibility but improved willingness to communicate.

Plan/recommendations:
- Progress since last week suggests emerging accuracy with final consonants and slightly more consistent /k/ attempts. Continue at current level to consolidate.
- Encourage parents to highlight final sounds in natural play (e.g., "You found the hat-t") and praise any attempts.
- Next session: continue CVC final /p, t, m/, maintain focus on establishing /k/ in isolation and CV, and add a few simple minimal pairs for /t/ vs /k/ if attention allows.

Parent report:
- Mother shared that he now sometimes corrects himself when leaving off a sound (e.g., “cu…cup!”). She has noticed clearer words like “cup” and “ham,” though /k/ words are still sounding like /t/ ("tar" for "car"). No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Client entered happily and quickly engaged with a car and animal play set. Good participation overall; brief episodes of silliness when tasks became more challenging, but he responded to gentle redirection. Tolerated structured turn-taking games.

Goals/therapy activities:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (p, t, m) – imitated and emerging spontaneous
- Practiced CVC words ("cup, cap, map, ham, hat, cat") at the imitated word level and then in simple carrier phrases ("my ___," "big ___") with models.
- Accuracy in imitation improved; he produced many final /p/ and /m/ sounds clearly with only light reminders. Final /t/ is emerging; produced several accurate examples today, though still omitted /t/ when speaking quickly.
- Beginning to carry over some final consonants in short spontaneous comments during play, especially for /m/ (e.g., “yum,” “ham”).

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued with “back sound” teaching using mirror and visual of a mouth. In isolation, /k/ was produced more reliably with less effort than in previous sessions.
- At the CV level ("ka, ku"), there were a few more accurate /k/ productions, but fronting to /t/ remains common. Client could sometimes distinguish the SLP’s /k/ vs /t/ when listening.

3. Early minimal pairs /t/ vs /k/ (listening and imitation)
- Introduced simple minimal pairs ("tea/key," "toe/coat") at a listening level first. Client did fairly well identifying which word the clinician said when paired with visuals.
- When attempting to imitate, he often produced both as /t/, but there were a few approximations of /k/ with maximal cueing.

4. Short functional phrases
- Used play routines (feeding animals, parking cars) to encourage 2–3 word phrases ("more food," "my car," "big cat"). Client imitated many phrases and initiated several 2-word combinations spontaneously.
- Intelligibility within the session was slightly improved, especially when he slowed down and watched the clinician’s mouth.

Plan/recommendations:
- Noted small but consistent gains in final consonant production and early self-monitoring. Continue at current level while building consistency.
- Home practice: families to continue emphasizing final sounds in a few target words and model clear /k/ vs /t/ contrasts during play, without pressuring for perfection.
- Next session: maintain work on CVC final /p, t, m/, continue /k/ isolation and CV, and expand minimal pair listening games as tolerated.

Goals/therapy activities:

Plan/recommendations:

Goals and session activities:
1. Establish baseline for overall speech sound production
- Collected an informal speech sample in play and structured naming tasks.

2. Initial /s/ at word level (imitation)
- Introduced initial /s/ in simple words (sun, sock, soup, soap, see).

3. Initial /f/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Practiced /f/ in syllables ("faa," "fee," "foo") and simple words (fish, foot, fun).

- With verbal cue to “bite your lip and blow,” child could briefly shape an accurate /f/ in isolation; carryover into words was inconsistent.

4. CV and CVC syllable shapes
- Practiced consonant-vowel (CV) and consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) structures using picture cards and play.
- CV shapes generally intact (e.g., "bee," "moo"); CVC words often missing final consonant ("bee" for "bed," "pi" for "pig").
- With immediate imitation and clinician emphasizing the final sound, child occasionally added the final consonant but did not yet do this independently.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to focus on initial /s/ and /f/ at the imitated word level, and on marking final consonants in CVC words.

- Self-corrections continued to appear when prompted, indicating ongoing awareness but not a major shift from recent performance.

2. Initial /f/ in phrases and conversation
- Target words: fish, foot, four, fun, farm, food, five, face, phone, fairy.
- Child maintained previously demonstrated accuracy levels, producing /f/ clearly in many phrase-level and some conversational contexts.
- Occasional /p/ substitutions persisted but were responsive to light cueing.

3. Final consonants in CVC words and phrases
- Revisited high-frequency words (bed, bus, dog, cat, cup, hat, pig, sun) and short phrases ("big bus," "red hat," "hot dog").
- Child continued to mark final consonants reliably in structured tasks and showed similar levels of carryover into short phrases and simple conversational turns as in recent sessions.

4. Initial /k/ at word level
- Practiced key, car, cow, cup, cat in a game format.
- Child produced several accurate /k/ words with moderate to maximal cueing, reflecting stable performance compared to prior weeks.
- Fronting persisted in less structured speech.

Plan/recommendations:
- Skills for /s/ and /f/ appear to have reached a stable level at short sentence/conversational contexts, with room for continued generalization and refinement.
- Final consonant production is more consistent in structured activities and is gradually emerging in more natural contexts.
- Initial /k/ remains an emerging target, with ongoing need for focused practice.
- Home: caregiver encouraged to continue using everyday routines and books to elicit target words, reinforcing clear /s/, /f/, and final consonants, and gently practicing /k/ with simple words like "car" and "cup."
- Recommendation: continue therapy in a subsequent block to further generalize established sounds to broader conversational contexts and to build more consistent /k/ production.

Parent report:
- Caregiver (mom) shared that she is most concerned about how hard it is for unfamiliar adults to understand him. She notices he often leaves off the ends of words and says “t” or “d” for many other sounds. No major changes since the initial assessment.

Behaviour/engagement:
- 4-year-old boy, transitioned to therapy room with some hesitation but separated from mom with reassurance. Once engaged with toys, he was cheerful and talkative. Attention was fair; he needed intermittent redirection back to tasks but generally participated.

Goals / session focus:
1) Establish production of early consonants in isolation (p, b, m, t, d, k, g)
- Probed a range of consonants in isolation and in simple CV syllables during play. He could imitate /p, b, m/ in isolation with good accuracy when given a clear model and visual cueing (watching clinician’s mouth). /t, d/ were often produced with an added vowel ("tuh, duh"). /k, g/ were fronted to /t, d/ in most attempts despite maximal verbal, visual, and some tactile cues (e.g., touching throat, cueing tongue "at the back").

2) Final consonant production at word level (CVC words)
- Baseline probes for final /p, m, t/ in single words (e.g., “cup, nap, map, hat, sit”) in imitation. He frequently omitted the final consonant or replaced it with a neutral vowel (e.g., “cu_,” “si_”). Occasional accurate final /p/ with intensive modeling and segmenting ("cu—P"). Overall low accuracy; remained at highly supported, imitated level.

3) Initial /k/ and /g/ at syllable and word level
- Targeted initial /k/ and /g/ in CV syllables ("ku, ki, go, ga") using mirror, tongue-back visual cue, and play-based activities (feeding toy animals). Consistent fronting to /t, d/ despite maximal cueing; only rare approximations of /k/ in isolation. Not yet ready to move beyond imitation.

4) Overall intelligibility in simple play
- During unstructured play, speech was often difficult to understand without contextual support. Frequent final consonant deletion and fronting patterns noted. He was talkative and attempted to communicate, but required frequent clarification requests.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue weekly therapy focusing on establishing accurate production of final consonants (especially /p, m, t/) in imitation and increasing awareness of "back" sounds /k, g/ in isolation.
- Home practice: caregiver to practice simple CVC words with final /p/ (e.g., "cup, up, nap") using slow, exaggerated models and pausing for his attempt. Encourage praise for any attempt at a final sound, not just perfect productions.
- Will monitor tolerance for tactile cues and consider additional visual supports (picture cards, gesture cues) next session.

Goals / session focus:

Accuracy improved across the session: started with frequent omissions, but by mid-session he produced a clear final /p/ on many trials, especially "up" and "cup." Still required significant support, but a few clear productions were noted in structured drill.

- During play, the clinician highlighted final sounds (e.g., “Look, cuP!”) and had him identify if he heard the "end sound." He showed emerging awareness by sometimes nodding or repeating the clinician’s model with more emphasis on the final consonant, though spontaneous use of final sounds remained rare.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned with some hesitation but separated from Mom with reassurance. He warmed up with toys and became more talkative in play. Attention was fair; he preferred self-directed play and needed frequent redirection back to sound practice. He responded well to visual supports and silly games.

Goals / session focus:
1) Establish /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Practiced /k/ in isolation using mirror, tongue depressor for awareness (no intraoral stimulation), and “cough” trick. Able to approximate /k/ in isolation in about half of opportunities with maximal verbal and visual cueing.
- In CV syllables ("koo, kee, kah"), productions often shifted to /t/ ("too, tee, tah"). When cued to “make the sound in the back,” he could occasionally correct with hand cue to throat.

2) Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted high-frequency words in play (e.g., "cup, up, map, mat, pop, mop"). At the imitated word level, he produced the final consonant clearly in some trials but frequently omitted it or added a schwa ("muh" for "m").
- Needed models plus visual cue (pointing to a “sound dot” at the end of the word). Accuracy was higher when words were broken into two parts (e.g., "cu—p").

3) Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Introduced /f/ as “lip-bite windy sound.” With mirror and clinician model, he could sometimes place his teeth on his lip but often produced /p/ or /h/ instead.
- In CV syllables ("foo, fee, fah"), productions were mostly /pV/ or /hV/. He responded best when reminded to “keep lips together and blow slowly.”

4) Syllable shapes (CV and CVCV)
- Observed spontaneous use of CV and reduplicated CVCV ("mama, dada, baba") in play. Attempted alternating CVCV words (e.g., "bunny, teddy"), with some simplification ("buh-ee" for "bunny").
- Used clapping to mark each syllable; he joined in and appeared to enjoy the activity, though speech productions were often reduced.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue targeting /k/ in isolation and simple CV syllables next session; maintain focus at sound and syllable level until productions are more consistent.
- For home practice, encouraged Mom to model and emphasize final sounds in simple words during play (e.g., "cup-P," "up-P"), without pressuring for imitation.
- Plan to introduce simple picture cards for CVC words next week to increase structure while keeping activities play-based.

Parent report:
Mom reported no big changes since last visit but feels she is “hearing the ends of words a tiny bit more” when he is really focused. She has been trying the strategy of emphasizing final sounds at home. She noted he still often says "t" for "k" in words like "cat" and "car."

Behaviour/engagement:
Client separated from Mom more easily today and entered the room willingly. He engaged well with cars and animal toys and was generally cooperative. Attention to adult-directed tasks was improved; he could participate in short drill games between play turns. Occasional silliness but easily redirected.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued work on /k/ using mirror and “cough” strategy. Accuracy in isolation was noticeably improved compared to last week; he produced a clear /k/ in most attempts with moderate verbal and visual cues.
- In CV syllables ("koo, kah, kee"), he produced a correct /k/ onset more often, though /t/ substitutions still occurred. Back-of-tongue cue and hand-to-throat gesture supported more consistent productions.

2) /k/ in initial word position (CVC words)
- Trialed a small set of words ("car, key, cow, cat") at the imitated level. With segmented modeling (breaking the word into initial sound + rest of word), he was able to produce an accurate /k/ at the start of several words, though not yet consistent.
- When given only a full word model, he tended to revert to /t/ ("tar" for "car").

3) Final consonant production in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Practiced with picture cards and a “feed the animal” game. At the imitated level, final consonants were present more frequently than previous session, especially for /p/ and /m/.
- He still occasionally omitted the final sound or added a vowel (“cu-puh”). Visual cue (tapping a dot after the word) and slowing the word helped increase accuracy.

4) Initial /f/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Reviewed /f/ with mirror and “bite lip, blow” description. Able to achieve the correct posture more frequently today, though he needed frequent reminders to keep lips together and blow.
- In CV syllables ("foo, fee"), approximations were closer to /f/ than last week, with fewer /p/ substitutions. Still required models and moderate cueing.

Plan / recommendations:
- Given improved accuracy with /k/ in isolation, will continue to strengthen CV syllables and gradually increase practice at the word level in upcoming sessions.
- For home, suggested Mom pick 3–4 “final sound” words (e.g., up, pop, map) and play quick turn-taking games, modeling clear final sounds and praising any attempts.
- Plan to continue shaping /f/ and monitor readiness to move /k/ into more consistent word-level practice.

Parent report:
Mom reported that over the past week he started saying "car" and "cow" with a clearer "back sound" at times, especially when reminded. She noted that some words are much clearer with family members, but unfamiliar listeners still ask for repetition. She feels he is more aware of when he is "not quite right" and sometimes tries again on his own.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client came into the therapy room independently and chose activities quickly. He was highly engaged in turn-taking games and tolerated short drill periods between play turns. Attention and cooperation were good, with minimal need for redirection. He responded well to specific praise.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ initial at word level (CVC words)
- Focused on initial /k/ words ("car, key, cow, cat, coat, cup") at the imitated word level. Accuracy was much stronger this week, with many clear /k/ productions when given a model and brief cue to “lift the back of the tongue.”
- Introduced simple carrier phrase "my ___" ("my car," "my cow") with supported imitation. He was able to maintain /k/ in some phrase attempts, though accuracy decreased compared to single words.

2) /k/ in isolation and syllables (maintenance)
- Briefly revisited /k/ in isolation and CV syllables to warm up. He produced consistent /k/ in isolation and in simple syllables with minimal cueing, suggesting this level is becoming solid.

3) Final consonant production in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Continued with picture-based drill in a game format. At the imitated word level, he included final consonants more consistently than in prior weeks, particularly for /p/ and /m/ (e.g., "map, mop, pop"), with occasional omissions.
- For final /t/ ("hat, mat, boat"), there were more variable productions, with some omissions or added vowels (“ha-tuh”). Using a slow model and tapping for the last sound helped him approximate final /t/ more clearly.

4) Initial /f/ in CV syllables and simple words
- Practiced /f/ in CV syllables ("fee, foo, fah") and introduced a small set of words ("fish, fun, four") in imitation. When cued to "bite your lip and blow," he produced a recognizable /f/ much of the time, though occasional /p/ substitutions persisted.
- He benefited from watching the clinician’s mouth in the mirror and seemed to enjoy “blowing the windy sound” to move small paper pieces.

Plan / recommendations:
- Given the noticeable jump in /k/ accuracy at the word level, plan to continue /k/ initial words and gradually increase short carrier phrases next session.
- For home practice, encouraged Mom to use a few /k/ words (car, cow, key) during daily routines, modeling clearly and inviting him to “try the back sound,” but without pressure.
- Continue work on final consonants, especially final /t/, and support emerging /f/ accuracy.

Parent report:
Mom shared that he is now saying "car" and "cup" more clearly in play and sometimes uses them in short phrases like "my car" at home with her model. She still hears many dropped final sounds but feels they are “popping in” more often. No concerns with hearing or overall health this week.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned smoothly and was eager to show the clinician his toy car. He remained engaged in structured tasks for longer stretches and responded well to visual schedules. Some mild distractibility toward the end of the session but generally cooperative and motivated.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ initial at word and carrier phrase level
- Continued practice of initial /k/ words ("car, cup, cat, coat, key, cow") in imitation. Accuracy at the word level remained strong overall, with mostly clear /k/ productions when given a model and light cueing.
- Expanded practice in short carrier phrases ("my car," "big cat," "go car") at the imitated phrase level. He was able to maintain the /k/ in many phrase attempts, although accuracy decreased when the phrase length increased or when attention waned.

2) /k/ in simple two-word combinations in play
- During structured play, the clinician modeled and elicited short two-word combinations (e.g., "push car," "blue cup") with picture support. With modeling, he produced several accurate attempts, though some reverted to /t/ (“push tar”).

3) Final consonant production (CVC: /p, m, t/)
- Continued work with picture cards in a turn-taking game. Final /p/ and /m/ were present in many imitated trials; final /t/ remained more inconsistent, with a mix of clear productions, omissions, and added vowels.
- He showed increased awareness, sometimes pausing and attempting to “add the end” after a reminder.

4) Initial /f/ in words
- Practiced initial /f/ words ("fish, four, fun, food") in imitation. When visually cued to bite his lower lip and blow, he produced several clear /f/ sounds, but still needed consistent reminders.
- In spontaneous play language, /f/ was not yet observed without cueing.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue consolidating /k/ at the phrase level next session, with a mix of high-success words and some new items.
- Maintain focus on final consonants, particularly final /t/, using simple games at home (e.g., emphasizing "hat," "feet" in books).
- Encourage parents to model short two-word phrases with /k/ words and praise any attempts to copy, without correcting every error.

Parent report:
Mom noted that he is using more short phrases overall (e.g., "my car," "more juice") and that some /k/ words sound clearer even when she does not remind him. She still hears many missing final sounds but feels he is trying more. No new concerns reported.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client entered the room happily and quickly engaged with the therapy materials. He demonstrated good participation in both play-based and more structured activities. He tolerated brief drill tasks and seemed proud when praised for “strong sounds.” Mild fatigue at the very end of session.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ initial in carrier phrases and short sentences
- Practiced /k/ words in simple carrier phrases ("I see ___," "my ___," "go ___") at the imitated phrase level. He was able to maintain /k/ in many phrases with a model, although accuracy still dropped when phrases were longer or when he spoke quickly.
- Trialed short, repetitive sentences ("I see a cat," "I see a car") in a picture book. He produced some accurate /k/ sounds in this context but required models and occasional segmenting.

2) /k/ in structured play, emerging spontaneous use
- During play with cars and animals, the clinician modeled /k/ words and encouraged him to request items (e.g., "car please," "cow please"). He produced several imitated phrases with correct /k/ and a few more independent attempts with variable accuracy.

3) Final consonants in CVC words
- Continued practice with final /p, m, t/ in a picture game. Accuracy was similar to last week: final /p/ and /m/ were often present in imitation; final /t/ remained more variable.
- He benefited from a visual of three “sound dots” to highlight beginning, middle, and end sounds and responded well to reminders to “tap the last dot.”

4) Initial /f/ in words and CV syllables
- Reviewed /f/ in CV syllables and practiced initial /f/ words ("fish, four, fun, feet"). Accuracy remained at a similar level to last session: he could produce clear /f/ with visual and verbal cues but rarely did so without support.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to work on stabilizing /k/ in short phrases and simple sentences next session, aiming for more consistent accuracy.
- Maintain current final consonant and /f/ targets, as skills are emerging but not yet ready for the next level.
- For home, encouraged Mom to highlight /k/ words during shared book reading and to pause for him to try, praising effort and any clear productions.

Parent report:

Parent report:
- Caregiver shared that they are most concerned about how hard it is for unfamiliar people to understand the child, especially with longer words and when excited.
- Parent notices frequent omissions of sounds at the ends of words and difficulty with /s/ and /f/ in everyday speech. No major changes since initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned to the therapy room with brief hesitation, then engaged well with toys and activities.
- Attention was variable; needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to structured tasks but responded well to visual choices and play-based routines.

Therapy goals and observations:
1) Initial /f/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Practiced /f/ in isolation using a “bite your lip, blow” cue; child produced an approximated /f/ in about half of attempts with maximal verbal and visual cueing.
- At CV syllable level ("foo, fah, fee"), productions were often stopped to /p/; a few clear /f/ productions achieved with slowed rate and mirror support.
- At initial word level in imitation (e.g., "fish, fun, five"), accuracy was low and child frequently substituted /p/; needed frequent reminders to use teeth-on-lip.

2) Initial /s/ in isolation and simple syllables (imitation)
- Introduced /s/ as a “quiet snake sound.” In isolation, child could approximate a prolonged /s/ with jaw stability and tongue behind teeth in about 3/10 attempts; other attempts were distorted or substituted with /t/.
- At CV syllables ("see, soo"), accuracy decreased; child tended to insert a vowel or stop consonant before the /s/.
- Benefited from auditory bombardment and watching clinician’s mouth; tolerates visual cueing well.

3) Final consonants in CVC words (primarily /p, m, t/ in imitation)
- Targeted simple CVC words in play (e.g., "map, mop, mat, mom, top, tap"). Child consistently produced the initial consonant and vowel but omitted final consonants in most attempts.
- With simultaneous productions and hand-tapping cues for “end sounds,” child produced a few clearer final /p/ and /m/ endings.
- Marking of final consonants remains emerging; still largely absent in spontaneous play.

4) Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV) in play
- Observed frequent use of CV and CVCV (same) patterns (e.g., "mama, dada, baby"), with reduced consonant accuracy but overall syllable structure present.
- Longer multisyllabic words were reduced (e.g., "nana" for "banana").

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to establish /f/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables with high levels of support.
- Maintain focus on marking final consonants in simple CVC words using visual hand-tapping cues.
- Home practice: caregiver to model slow, clear /f/ and /s/ sounds in front of a mirror during daily routines (e.g., "fish, soap"), emphasizing “end sounds” in a few familiar words without pressuring the child to repeat.
- Next session: recheck /f/ and /s/ in isolation; consider adding more movement-based cues for final consonants.

Parent report:
Mom shared that she and daycare staff notice that he is “hard to understand” when he’s excited. She reported frequent omissions of sounds at the ends of words and difficulty with /k/ and /s/ sounds. No major changes since the evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned into the room with some hesitation but warmed up quickly with preferred toys. He was generally cheerful and cooperative, with short attention to tabletop tasks; needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to structured practice.

Goals and session observations:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted final consonants in simple CVC words (e.g., “cup, map, cat”) at the imitated word level.
- Client frequently omitted final consonants or replaced them with a neutral vowel (e.g., “cu_,” “ma_”).
- With maximal verbal cueing (e.g., “stop your sound,” “close your lips at the end”) and visual support, he produced clearer final consonants in a small number of trials, but consistency was low.

2. Initial /k/ in syllables and simple words
- Practiced /k/ in isolation and CV syllables (“koo, kah, kee”) using a “back sound” cue and mirror.
- Client tended to substitute /t/ for /k/ (“tea” for “key”).
- With hand-under-chin tactile cue and slowed rate, he achieved a few accurate /k/ sounds in isolation and in CV syllables; accuracy dropped when moving to CVC words (e.g., “cat, car”).

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Introduced /s/ as a “long, quiet snake sound.”
- In isolation, client could approximate /s/ intermittently but often added a vowel (“suh”) or changed to /ʃ/.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “see, soo”), he required maximal verbal and visual cueing; productions were mostly distorted or stopped.

4. Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- During play, modeled and elicited CV and CVCV (reduplicated) forms (e.g., “moo, baa, baba, mama”).
- Client produced many CV and CVCV reduplicated forms spontaneously; accuracy decreased in alternating CVCV (e.g., “nana” for “banana”).

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue weekly therapy focusing on final consonants in CVC words and establishing /k/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables.
- Home practice: encourage “stop your sound” at the end of words like “up, in, out,” praising any attempts to mark final sounds; model slow, clear speech during play. Provide caregiver with picture list of 5 CVC words to model, not to drill.

Goals and session observations:
1. Final consonant production in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Practiced final /p, m, t/ at imitated word level (e.g., “cup, map, mat, ham”).

- Still omitted final sounds in spontaneous speech, but during practice trials he produced clearer final consonants in roughly half of the opportunities with moderate cueing.

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and CV/CVC
- Continued to work on /k/ in isolation using tongue-back imagery and mirror.
- Client produced more accurate /k/ sounds in isolation with moderate cueing and less need for hand-under-chin support.
- At CV level (“koo, key, kah”), he was able to imitate more consistent /k/ productions, though he often reverted to /t/ at the CVC word level (e.g., “tat” for “cat”).

- Reintroduced /s/ with “snake sound” visuals.

- Targeted alternating CVCV words (e.g., “nana/banana, baby, bunny”) in play.

- At the CVC level, he produced several accurate imitations (e.g., “car”) but still reverted to /t/ in spontaneous attempts; overall, fewer substitutions than in previous sessions.

- CV productions (“see, so, sue”) were somewhat more intelligible; still a tendency to add a vowel (“suh”) or distort, but he needed slightly fewer cues for correct tongue placement.

- Introduced listening task with /s/ blends (e.g., “stop” vs. “top”) using minimal pairs.
- Client demonstrated emerging awareness by pointing to the correct picture more often when the clinician emphasized the /s/.
- No expectation for accurate production at this time; focus was auditory discrimination.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue strengthening final consonant production and /k/ in simple words; maintain work on /s/ in isolation and CV. Continue auditory discrimination for /s/ blends.
- Home practice: model and practice a short list of final /p, m/ words during daily routines; introduce a simple listening game at home (“Did I say top or stop?”) to build awareness of /s/ blends without pressure to say them correctly.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned to the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from Mom with reassurance. He was generally cooperative and engaged with preferred toys (cars, animals). Attention to adult-directed tasks was fair; he needed frequent reminders to look at the clinician and to wait for his turn to speak.

Goals and session observations:
1. Establish /f/ in isolation and initial position
- Baseline probing completed for /f/ in isolation and at the initial word level. Client was inconsistently able to produce a clear /f/ in isolation, often substituting /p/ or /b/ or adding a vowel ("fuh"). With maximal verbal cues ("bite your lip and blow") and visual modeling, he could approximate /f/ in isolation in some attempts.
- At the imitated word level (e.g., "fish, fun, four"), accuracy was low; most productions were stopped (e.g., "pish" for "fish").

2. Establish /s/ in isolation and initial position
- Baseline assessment for /s/ in isolation and initial word position. Client was able to imitate a prolonged /s/ in isolation intermittently when given direct visual cues to smile and keep the tongue behind the teeth. Productions were often distorted or backed, and he occasionally substituted /d/.
- At the imitated word level (e.g., "sun, soup, see"), productions were inconsistent and often reduced or changed to /d/ or /t/.

3. Syllable shape inventory (CV, CVC, CVCV)
- Informal sampling showed that Client used a variety of syllable shapes in play, including CV, CVC, and some CVCV (e.g., "mama, dada, bunny"). Final consonants were sometimes omitted in spontaneous speech, particularly for /t/ and /k/.

4. Overall speech intelligibility in play
- During unstructured play, Client used many 2–4 word phrases (e.g., "my car go," "I want that one"). Intelligibility to the clinician unfamiliar with his speech was reduced, with frequent need for repetition and clarification. Mom was able to interpret many of his intended words based on context.

Plan/recommendations:
- Begin direct treatment on /f/ and /s/ at the isolation and simple syllable level next session.
- Encourage Mom to model clear /f/ and /s/ words in everyday routines (e.g., "fish, food, soap, sun") without pressuring Client to repeat.
- Continue to monitor overall intelligibility and syllable shapes as we build sound accuracy.
- Plan weekly sessions to support sound establishment prior to school entry.

Goals / Session Targets:
1. Baseline for overall speech sound production

2. Initial /f/ in isolation and syllables
- Introduced /f/ sound with visual cue for “biting lip and blowing air.”
- In isolation, child produced /f/ correctly with simultaneous modeling in about half of attempts; tended to substitute /p/ or omit airflow.
- In simple syllables (e.g., “foo, fah, fee”), accuracy decreased; required maximal verbal and visual cueing and slowed rate.

- Practiced “snake sound” /s/ with mirror.
- In isolation, child approximated /s/ but often added a brief vowel (“suh”). With verbal reminder to “keep tongue behind teeth and no voice,” was able to hold a closer /s/ for a few seconds in several attempts.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “see, soo”), child often produced /d/ or /z/; success improved when clinician modeled slowly and used hand cue for “long sound.”

4. Initial /sh/ in isolation
- Introduced /sh/ as “quiet sound.” Child tended to produce /s/ instead.
- With modeling and cue to round lips, child could approximate /sh/ in isolation intermittently, but not yet stable.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to build awareness of /f/, /s/, and /sh/ at isolation and simple syllable level before moving into words.
- Suggested parent model “fish,” “feet,” and “fun” during play and mealtimes, emphasizing lip placement and airflow without asking for constant imitation.

Goals / session focus:
1. Establish production of /k/ in isolation and simple syllables (CV)
- Baseline: Fronting observed (/t/ for /k/) in spontaneous speech (e.g., "tat" for "cat").
- With direct modeling and visual cue (pointing to "back sound"), child produced /k/ in isolation inconsistently; able to achieve a clear /k/ in about half of attempts with maximal verbal and visual cueing.
- In CV syllables ("koo, kay, key"), child often reverted to /t/; required simultaneous production with clinician and hand-to-throat cue to support placement.

2. Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Child often omitted or stopped /f/ to /p/ in conversation (e.g., "pish" for "fish").
- In isolation, could approximate /f/ with strong visual model ("bite lip, blow air"); accuracy inconsistent, with frequent voicing or lip closure errors.
- In CV syllables ("fee, foo, faa"), productions were mostly approximations, requiring repeated models and verbal reminders to use "lip bite" and quiet air.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation
- Child produced /s/ with lateral airflow and occasional /sh/-like substitutions in spontaneous speech.
- With mirror and snake visual, could produce a closer approximation of /s/ with significant support (verbal cueing for tongue placement and gentle airflow); accuracy low but some clear exemplars achieved.

4. Syllable shapes (CVC, CVCV) with clear consonant marking
- During play, child produced a range of CVC and CVCV words but often reduced final consonants and altered target sounds.
- With modeling and slowed rate, could mark some final consonants in imitation (e.g., "cup," "map"), but needed frequent reminders and segmentation.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build foundational placement for /k/, /f/, and /s/ at isolation and simple syllable levels.
- Encourage parent to model "back sound" /k/ during daily routines (e.g., "car, cookie, coat") without pressuring child to repeat.
- Provide parent with simple cues for /f/ ("bite lip, blow") to use during book reading.
- Next session: re-check stimulability for /k/ and /f/, and continue play-based CV/CVC practice with high modeling.

- Word-level /k/ remained accurate in imitation with minimal cueing across familiar vocabulary.
- In structured phrases and short sentences ("I see the car," "my cat is big"), child continued to produce /k/ with similar accuracy to prior sessions.
- Spontaneous use of /k/ during play remained variable; no clear increase from last week.

2. Initial /f/ in words and two-word phrases
- Child maintained similar accuracy for initial /f/ in imitated words; minimal change noted.
- Two-word phrases with /f/ ("fun fish," "fast fox") were produced with similar levels of support and accuracy as in previous sessions.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV
- Short practice segments for /s/ continued. Child was able to produce intermittent clear /s/ in isolation with maximal cueing, but inconsistency persisted.
- CV syllables remained difficult, with frequent shifts to /sh/ or other approximations.

4. Final consonants in CVC words
- Practiced final /p, t, m, n/ in structured tasks. Child showed stable performance: clearer endings when given segmentation/tapping, but frequent omissions in connected speech.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue with current hierarchy levels, focusing on maintaining gains and gradually encouraging more independent /k/ and /f/ use in structured play.
- Parent encouraged to model slow, clear speech and to emphasize target sounds within child’s longer sentences (e.g., repeating and expanding child’s utterances with clear /k/ and /f/).
- Next session: maintain current targets; may begin planning for next block’s goals depending on stability of performance.

Parent report:
Mom shared that she and daycare staff find him "hard to understand" when he's excited or talking in longer sentences. She notices he often leaves off sounds at the ends of words and sometimes says "tup" for "cup" or "do" for "go." No major changes since the evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned with some hesitation but separated from mom with encouragement. Once in the room, he warmed up quickly and engaged well with toy cars and a farm set. Attention to adult-directed tasks was fair; needed frequent redirection from self-directed play but responded to visual supports and choices.

Goals / session focus:
1) Establish production of /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Practiced /k/ in isolation using "cough" and "back sound" cues. He was able to approximate the sound with maximal verbal and visual support (mirror, open-mouth posture) but frequently substituted /t/. 
- At CV level (e.g., "ku," "ki," "ko"), he produced a mix of accurate /k/ and fronted /t/, with better accuracy when the clinician provided simultaneous production and slowed rate.

2) Initial /k/ at single-word level (imitation)
- Target words: "key, car, cow, cookie." At this time, productions were mostly imitated and often fronted to /t/ (e.g., "tar" for "car").
- When he achieved a good /k/ in isolation immediately beforehand, he occasionally carried it into the word, but this was inconsistent and required heavy prompting.

3) Final consonants (general awareness)
- During play, clinician modeled CVC words with final /p, t, m/ (e.g., "cup, hot, mom") and drew attention to the "sound at the end" using visual cueing (tapping a picture).
- Client rarely added final sounds independently; he repeated some CVC words after a model but often omitted the final consonant despite maximal cues.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build awareness of back sounds and final consonants at the isolation and simple syllable level.
- Home practice: parent encouraged to practice "back sound" /k/ in front of a mirror with short "ku" and "ki" games, keeping it playful and brief (1–2 minutes). Emphasized focusing on correct attempts, not perfection.
- Next session: continue /k/ in isolation and CV syllables; further probe final consonant production in high-interest words.

Parent report:
Mom reported that he is now occasionally trying to copy her when she exaggerates "back sounds," especially with "car" and "cookie." She still finds him difficult to understand in conversation but feels he is "trying harder" when reminded.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client entered the therapy room without difficulty and appeared eager to play. He was talkative and enjoyed pretend play with a garage and cars. Required some reminders to stay seated for structured drill but was generally cooperative and motivated by turn-taking games and stickers.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Showed a noticeable increase in accuracy for /k/ in isolation with visual cues (mirror, "tongue back" prompts). He produced a clearer /k/ more consistently than last week, often after a single model.
- At CV level ("ku, ki, ko"), he produced more accurate /k/ productions, especially when the clinician used a slow rate and tapped his shoulder for the "back" sound. Fronting to /t/ still occurred, but he showed emerging self-correction when given time to repeat.

2) Initial /k/ at imitated word level
- Target words: "car, key, cow, cookie, cat." Compared to last session, he had more successful imitations with clear /k/, particularly for "car" and "cow" when paired with picture cards.
- Still needed moderate verbal cues ("back sound" and slowed rate), but he responded well to backward chaining (e.g., "ar" → "car").

3) Final consonants (awareness and imitation)
- Practiced CVC words with final /p, t, m/ in a picture game ("cup, hat, mop, hot, mom"). With direct imitation and pointing cues, he produced some final consonants more clearly than in the previous session.
- Omission of final sounds remained frequent in spontaneous speech, but he tolerated cueing and was able to mark some final consonants in structured practice.

4) Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Observed a variety of syllable shapes in play, including CV and CVCV (e.g., "bunny," "daddy"). Longer words often had reduced clarity but most syllables were present.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue targeting /k/ in CV syllables and initial position at the word level, as he is demonstrating a positive response to cueing.
- Maintain focus on final consonant awareness with high-interest CVC words.
- Home practice: parent to choose 3–4 /k/ words (e.g., car, cow, cookie, key) and model slowly, encouraging him to copy when engaged; praise any attempts at the back sound.
- Next session: continue current level; consider introducing simple phrase frames ("my car") if initial /k/ accuracy remains steady in imitation.

Parent report:
Mom shared that he is now saying "car" and "cookie" more clearly at home when she reminds him to use his "back sound." She notices fewer "tar" productions. Final sounds are still often dropped, but she feels his speech is a "little clearer" in short phrases.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned smoothly and appeared comfortable. He was very engaged in a farm and animal game and responded well to turn-taking and simple visual schedules. Attention to structured trials improved; he stayed with table activities for longer periods compared to earlier sessions.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ initial at imitated word level
- Target words: "car, key, cow, cookie, cat, cup, kite." Accuracy improved compared to last week; he produced a clear /k/ in many trials with moderate verbal and visual support.
- Fronting to /t/ still occurred but was less frequent. He demonstrated increasing ability to adjust his tongue position after a cue ("tongue back"), suggesting improved motor planning for /k/.

2) /k/ initial in simple carrier phrases (imitation)
- Introduced short phrases such as "my car," "big cow," and "go car" using picture supports.
- With a model, he was able to maintain his improved /k/ production in these short phrases in a portion of attempts, though he sometimes reverted to /t/ when the phrase length increased.
- Required moderate cueing (slowed rate, model, and pointing to the mouth) but tolerated this well.

3) Final consonants /p, t, m/ at word level (imitation)
- Used a picture game targeting CVC words: "cup, hat, mop, hot, map, mop, mom." He showed modest improvement in marking some final consonants when given direct imitation and a visual "tap" cue for the last sound.
- Final /m/ in "mom" and "ham" was generally stronger; final /p/ and /t/ remained more variable.

4) General intelligibility in play
- During free play, his speech remained reduced in clarity, especially in longer utterances; however, he showed occasional spontaneous use of clearer /k/ in familiar words (e.g., "my car" during car play) without prompting.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen /k/ initial at word level and expand phrase-level practice as tolerated, as he is showing moderate, meaningful gains.
- Maintain structured practice for final /p, t, m/ with consistent visual cues.
- Home practice: encourage brief practice with "my car," "big cow" using toys, focusing on the back sound at the start of the word.
- Next session: continue word and short-phrase work for /k/; monitor for readiness to increase independence (reduced cues) if accuracy remains stable.

Parent report:

Behaviour/engagement:
Client arrived in a cheerful mood and quickly joined the clinician. He remained engaged in both tabletop games and floor play. Attention to task was good, with only brief breaks needed between structured activities. He was receptive to feedback and enjoyed earning small rewards.

Goals / session focus:

- Continued with carrier phrases such as "my car," "big cow," "red cup," and "go car" using picture scenes.

4) Syllable shapes and multisyllabic words (observation)
- In spontaneous language, he used a variety of 2–3 word phrases. Longer words (e.g., "banana," "dinosaur") often had all syllables present but some sounds were unclear or simplified.

Plan / recommendations:

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned easily and appeared confident. He participated well in all activities and responded positively to verbal praise. Attention and cooperation were good; he was able to complete longer sets of practice trials with brief movement breaks.

Goals / session focus:

Behaviour/engagement:
Client arrived in good spirits and eagerly joined the clinician. He was attentive and cooperative, with minimal need for redirection. He enjoyed both structured card games and pretend play, and he responded well to specific praise for his speech efforts.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ initial at word and short-phrase levels (stabilizing skills)
- Continued practice with a variety of /k/ initial words in a picture game. He maintained a high rate of accurate /k/ productions with only light cues or simple reminders.
- In short phrases ("my car," "big cow," "red cup"), he generally preserved the /k/ sound, even when the clinician provided fewer models. Occasional fronting to /t/ still occurred but was less frequent and often corrected with a brief cue.

- With a full model, he could usually maintain the /k/ but needed support to keep his speech rate slow enough for clarity.

- Home practice: reinforce short, positive practice sessions (1–2 minutes) with a small set of CVC words and simple phrases, ending on success.
- Next session: maintain similar goals while preparing for end-of-block summary and consideration of next steps.

Parent report:
Mom reported no major changes since last week. She continues to notice good /k/ sounds in many familiar words and ongoing difficulty with final consonants. She is interested in hearing about progress over the therapy block and recommendations moving forward.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned well and appeared comfortable with the routine. He participated in structured and play-based tasks with consistent effort. Attention and cooperation were in line with recent sessions.

Goals / session focus:
1) /k/ initial at word and sentence levels (end-of-block check)
- Reassessed /k/ in a variety of words and short sentences without prior warm-up. He produced a clear /k/ in the majority of structured opportunities with minimal cueing, similar to his recent performance.
- Some spontaneous accurate /k/ productions were observed in play, particularly with familiar vocabulary (e.g., "car," "cow," "cookie").

2) Final consonants /p, t, m/ in CVC words
- Rechecked final consonants using a mixed picture set. His pattern remained consistent with recent weeks: some clear final /p/ and /m/ productions in imitation, with more frequent omissions in spontaneous speech.
- Final /t/ remained the least consistent; he benefited from direct cues but did not yet mark this sound reliably without support.

3) Short phrases and sentences with target sounds (imitation)
- Practiced two- to three-word phrases and short sentences that included both /k/ initial and CVC words. He maintained his improved /k/ production in these contexts but continued to show variable final consonant marking.

4) Overall intelligibility and summary of block
- In spontaneous language, his intelligibility has improved somewhat for familiar listeners due to clearer /k/ productions and increased awareness of speech; however, final consonant deletion and other simplification patterns continue to impact clarity, especially for unfamiliar listeners.

Plan / recommendations:
- Recommend continued speech-language services to further support final consonant production and generalization of skills into longer phrases and conversation.
- Home practice: continue playful practice with /k/ words and a small set of CVC words, focusing on short, positive sessions and praising any attempts to use "end sounds."
- Next steps: share end-of-block summary with family, discuss scheduling for ongoing therapy, and consider adding new targets (e.g., other back sounds, additional final consonants) in future sessions while maintaining gains with /k/.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported ongoing concerns about clarity of speech with unfamiliar listeners. Noted that child is "chatty" at home but often leaves off sounds at the ends of words. No major changes since initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned to the therapy room with mild hesitation but separated from caregiver with reassurance.
- Engaged well with toys and books, required occasional redirection from self-directed play back to structured tasks.
- Participated in imitation tasks when given clear models and visual supports.

Goals / Observations:
1. Initial /f/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Practiced /f/ in isolation and simple CV syllables ("fa, fee, foo"). Child was able to approximate /f/ in isolation inconsistently with verbal cue "bite your lip and blow" and visual model.
- At the imitated word level (e.g., "fish, fan, foot, four"), productions were often stopped to /p/ or omitted ("pish" for "fish").
- Needed maximal verbal and visual cueing plus slowed rate. Accuracy was low but child was willing to attempt.

2. Initial /s/ at word level (imitation)
- Target words included "sun, soap, sock, soup." Child frequently substituted /d/ or omitted the initial consonant ("un" for "sun").
- With simultaneous production and direct visual cue to "keep tongue behind teeth and use quiet air," child produced a few clearer /s/ sounds, though consistency was limited.
- Child responded well to looking in mirror but required continuous cueing.

3. Final consonant production (CVC words in imitation)
- Focused on final /p, m, t/ in simple words ("cup, map, cat, ham").
- Child often omitted final consonants in spontaneous play; in imitation, could mark the final sound some of the time with strong emphasis from SLP.
- Productions were sometimes distorted or very quiet, suggesting emerging awareness but reduced consistency.

4. Functional play-based speech sample
- During play with farm animals and cars, child used mostly single words and short 2–3 word phrases (e.g., "my car," "go fast," "more bubbles").
- Final consonant deletion and reduced intelligibility were noted across contexts, especially for less familiar words.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue targeting initial /f/ and /s/ at the imitated syllable and word levels with heavy visual/verbal cues.
- Maintain focus on marking final consonants in CVC words during structured tasks.
- Encourage caregiver to model slow, clear speech at home and highlight final sounds ("cuP," "maP") in play without pressuring child to repeat every time.

Goals / Observations:
1. Initial /f/ at word level (imitation → supported spontaneous)
- Reviewed /f/ in isolation; child produced a clearer /f/ sound more consistently with the "bite-lip and blow" cue and visual model.
- Practiced words: "fish, fan, feet, fork, four." Accuracy in imitation improved; several words were produced with recognizable /f/ when given a single verbal reminder.
- In simple play routines (feeding animals "fish"), child began to produce "fish" independently after a few modeled trials, indicating early carryover.

2. Initial /s/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Used mirror and visual cue of "snake sound" to support production.
- Child produced /s/ in isolation more reliably today and was able to sustain airflow for several seconds with support.
- At word level ("sun, sock, soap, soup"), accuracy in imitation increased, though occasional substitutions (/d/ or omission) persisted. Fewer maximal cues were required; child responded to brief reminders like "teeth together" and "quiet air."

3. Final consonants in CVC words (imitation)
- Targeted final /p, m, t/ using picture cards ("cup, map, ham, cat, boat").
- Child showed better awareness of final sounds and sometimes attempted to self-correct after hearing the SLP emphasize the final consonant.
- With slowed rate and a visual cue (pointing to mouth for the last sound), child could clearly mark final /p/ and /m/ in many imitated trials; final /t/ remained more inconsistent.

4. Early /s/ blends at sound/cluster awareness level
- Introduced concept of "two sounds together" for /s/ blends (e.g., /s/ + /t/ for "st").
- Child was able to hear and identify when the SLP included vs. left out the /s/ in minimal pair contrasts ("top" vs. "stop") in a few trials, though production was not yet targeted.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Due to noticeable improvement, will continue building consistency with initial /f/ and /s/ at the word level and begin to incorporate more supported spontaneous productions in play.
- Maintain work on final consonants with emphasis on final /t/.
- Encourage caregiver to cue "snake sound" /s/ and "bite-lip" /f/ at home in short, playful routines (e.g., bath time, snack time), reinforcing successful attempts with specific praise.

Goals / Observations:
1. Initial /f/ at word and early phrase level (imitation → carrier phrase)
- Child produced /f/ in isolation with good consistency today, needing only brief reminders.
- At word level ("fish, four, five, feet, fan, food"), accuracy in imitation was high; occasional stopping to /p/ occurred when child rushed.
- Expanded to simple carrier phrases ("my fish," "more food," "four cars") with moderate success when the key word was first practiced in isolation and at the single word level.
- Child began to produce some phrases with /f/ independently in a structured game (e.g., "my fish" without direct model).

2. Initial /s/ at word level and simple phrases (imitation)
- Continued mirror work and "snake sound" cues.
- In isolation, /s/ was produced clearly in most attempts.
- At the imitated word level ("sun, soup, sock, soap, seal"), accuracy was noticeably improved compared to previous sessions, with fewer substitutions.
- Trialed simple two-word combinations such as "see sun" and "my sock" with moderate support; child could maintain /s/ in some phrases, though coarticulation occasionally affected clarity.

3. Final consonants in CVC words (imitation → cued spontaneous)
- Focused on final /p, m, t/ with picture scenes ("map, cup, ham, cat, boat, hat").
- Child showed increasing awareness of final sounds and sometimes spontaneously added the final consonant after hearing an emphasized model.
- With a visual cue (tapping the table for the last sound), child marked final /p/ and /m/ more consistently; /t/ still required more direct support but was present in some independent attempts.

4. Early awareness of /s/ blends (listening and imitation attempts)
- Used minimal pairs ("top/stop," "pin/spin") to highlight presence/absence of /s/.
- Child correctly identified which word contained the "snake sound" in several trials.
- Briefly attempted imitation of "stop" and "spin"; productions often reduced to "top" and "pin," indicating that full cluster production is still emerging.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Given moderate gains, will continue to strengthen initial /f/ and /s/ at the word and simple phrase levels, with more practice in short, structured play routines.
- Maintain emphasis on final consonants, particularly final /t/.
- Suggest caregiver play simple picture-naming games at home, emphasizing final sounds and praising any attempts to correct or add the last sound.
