Parent report:
- Parent reported noticeable improvement in child's clarity when using practiced sentences (e.g., "I want cookie," "I see a car").
- Caregiver shared that child sometimes corrects themselves after a reminder to "use your good /k/ sound."

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned smoothly and was very enthusiastic about participating in new games.
- Demonstrated strong engagement and was willing to repeat words and sentences multiple times.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in short sentences and structured conversation (imitation → emerging spontaneous)
- Practiced target sentences ("I see a car," "I want cookie," "I see a cow," "I like cats") with high accuracy in imitation and minimal cueing.
- In structured conversation during play (e.g., talking about what characters like, what they see), child independently used several /k/ words and short sentences with clear /k/.
- Overall performance reflects a meaningful step up in consistency and independence compared to previous weeks.

2. Initial /k/ in mixed phrase/sentence contexts with varied vocabulary
- Expanded /k/ vocabulary ("coat, cup, candy, corn") and embedded in phrases ("red coat," "big cup," "more candy").
- Child imitated these combinations with good accuracy and began to spontaneously use some of them when requesting items in play.
- Fewer fronting errors were observed, and child responded quickly to occasional corrective feedback.

3. Initial /f/ at word and phrase level (imitation → reduced cues)
- Continued practice with /f/ words ("fish, food, four, fun, fan") and short phrases ("my food," "four fish," "big fan").
- Child produced /f/ more consistently with lighter cueing, and was able to maintain correct placement across several consecutive trials.
- A few spontaneous /f/ words were heard in play (e.g., "food"), marking early generalization.

4. Final /p, m/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Practiced final consonants in a game format ("map, mop, nap, pop, mom, home").
- Child demonstrated improved accuracy for final /p/ and /m/ when given a visual "stop" cue and slowed rate; more words were produced with clear final consonants compared to earlier sessions.
- Still requires structured practice, but this represents a moderate gain.

Plan / recommendations:
- Next sessions will continue to build /k/ use in more natural conversational contexts while monitoring for consistency.
- Maintain /f/ at phrase level and encourage more spontaneous use in play.
- Provide caregiver with a short list of practiced sentences and words for home, emphasizing slow, clear models and praise for self-corrections.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported that child continues to use practiced /k/ sentences at home and that family can usually understand them.
- Parent did not notice major new changes this week but feels improvements from previous weeks have been maintained.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child was cooperative but appeared slightly tired; preferred to alternate between structured tasks and brief free play.
- With this balance, child remained engaged and responsive to cues.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in structured conversation (supported spontaneous)
- Engaged in play-based conversation around cars, animals, and food, encouraging use of /k/ words and sentences.
- Child produced multiple /k/ words and short sentences with good clarity when prompted, similar to last session.
- Occasional fronting errors occurred when excited or speaking quickly, but child responded to brief reminders.

2. Initial /k/ in varied sentence structures (imitation)
- Practiced slightly more complex sentences (e.g., "The car is fast," "I put cookie in cup").
- Child imitated these with moderate success; /k/ was generally present but overall sentence clarity varied depending on length and attention.
- Performance at this level was consistent with last week's gains, indicating consolidation.

3. Initial /f/ at word and phrase level (imitation)
- Targeted familiar /f/ words and phrases ("fish, four, fun," "my food," "four fish") in a picture game.
- Accuracy for /f/ remained stable: child produced /f/ correctly in many imitated trials with light to moderate cueing.
- Limited spontaneous /f/ use was observed today, similar to last session.

4. Final /p, m/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Continued practice of final /p, m/ in CVC words ("map, mop, nap, pop, mom, home") in a turn-taking game.
- Child produced some clear final consonants with visual and verbal cues; overall accuracy remained comparable to last week.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to support /k/ use in structured conversation while gradually varying sentence patterns.
- Maintain current /f/ and final consonant practice to stabilize skills before adding additional complexity.
- Encourage caregiver to keep using practiced sentences and to gently prompt child to slow down when speech becomes less clear.

Parent report:
- Parent stated that child's speech seems "about the same" as last week, with good clarity for practiced /k/ words but continued difficulty with unfamiliar words.
- Caregiver is continuing home practice a few times per week.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned well but required a bit more encouragement to start structured tasks today.
- Once engaged, child participated cooperatively, though attention occasionally drifted toward toys not related to the activity.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in structured conversation (supported spontaneous)
- Used storybooks and play scenarios to elicit /k/ words and short sentences.
- Child produced /k/ accurately in many prompted sentences (e.g., "I see a cat," "I want cookie") with minimal cueing, similar to previous sessions.
- Spontaneous use of /k/ remained present but did not show a noticeable increase in complexity or independence.

2. Initial /k/ in varied sentence structures (imitation)
- Practiced a mix of previously introduced and slightly new sentence patterns ("The cat is on the car," "I put cookie on plate").
- Child imitated these with moderate accuracy; /k/ was usually present but other consonant errors affected overall intelligibility.
- Performance was consistent with last week's level.

3. Initial /f/ at word and phrase level (imitation)
- Revisited /f/ words and short phrases using a board game.
- Child continued to produce /f/ with similar accuracy to prior sessions, benefiting from reminders to "bite your lip" and blow air.
- No clear change in spontaneous /f/ productions compared to last week.

4. Final /p, m/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Practiced CVC words with final /p/ and /m/ in a picture flip game.
- Child produced some accurate final consonants with cues, but omissions were still frequent; overall performance resembled last session.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain current targets and levels to support consolidation of gains before progressing.
- Continue to encourage slow, clear practice of /k/ sentences at home and occasional focused practice of /f/ and final consonants.
- Consider introducing a new motivating activity next week to support attention while keeping the same speech goals.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported that child is starting to use clearer /f/ words at home such as "food" and "four" when reminded.
- Parent also noted that teachers commented on improved clarity for certain practiced /k/ words during circle time.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child was cheerful and talkative today, initiating conversation with the clinician.
- Demonstrated good attention to both structured tasks and play-based activities with minimal need for redirection.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in structured and semi-spontaneous sentences
- Used play and simple role-play to elicit /k/ in a variety of short sentences ("I see a car," "The cat is in the cup," "I like cookies").
- Child produced /k/ accurately in most imitated and prompted sentences with minimal cueing.
- There was a slight increase in spontaneous use of /k/ in comments during play (e.g., "my car fast"), with /k/ often present and recognizable.

2. Initial /k/ in mixed word positions (imitation)
- Briefly probed /k/ in medial and final positions in simple words ("baking, rocket, book").
- Child was able to approximate /k/ in some of these new contexts with moderate cues, though accuracy was lower than for initial /k/.
- This provides preliminary information for potential future goal expansion.

3. Initial /f/ at word and phrase level (imitation → reduced cues)
- Practiced /f/ words ("fish, food, four, fun") and phrases ("my food," "four fish," "fun fish") in a card game.
- Child demonstrated improved consistency with /f/ and often needed only a brief verbal cue; fewer substitutions with /p/ were observed.
- A couple of spontaneous /f/ words ("food," "four") were heard in play without direct prompting.

4. Final /p, m/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Continued practice of final /p/ and /m/ in CVC words ("map, mop, nap, pop, mom, home").
- Child produced somewhat more consistent final consonants than in earlier sessions when given a visual "stop" cue and extra time.
- Final consonants remain an emerging skill but showed a small increase in accuracy compared to recent weeks.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue supporting /k/ use in short sentences and consider gradually incorporating more medial/final /k/ words as tolerated.
- Maintain /f/ at phrase level and encourage caregiver to highlight /f/ words during daily routines (e.g., "food," "four," "feet").
- Keep practicing final consonants in short, focused bursts at home, using a "stop the word" gesture as modeled.

Parent report:
- Parent reported that child continues to use practiced /k/ and /f/ words at home with generally good clarity but that longer sentences are still harder to understand.
- No major new concerns were reported; caregiver feels progress is "moving along" steadily.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned easily into the therapy room and chose to start with a favorite board game.
- Engagement was good throughout; child accepted cues and feedback without frustration.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in structured sentences and conversation (supported spontaneous)
- Engaged child in play-based conversation with a focus on /k/ words and short sentences.
- Child produced /k/ accurately in many prompted sentences, and spontaneous use of familiar /k/ words ("car," "cookie," "cat") remained consistent with last week.
- Overall performance suggests stable maintenance of gains rather than a new jump in skill level.

2. Initial /k/ in mixed word positions (imitation)
- Revisited medial/final /k/ probes ("rocket, baking, book").
- Child showed similar performance to last session, with some successful approximations in imitation but ongoing need for moderate cueing.
- Not yet ready to systematically target medial/final /k/ beyond brief probes.

3. Initial /f/ at word and phrase level (imitation)
- Continued practice of /f/ words and short phrases using picture cards.
- Child produced /f/ accurately in many imitated trials and required similar cueing as last session; spontaneous /f/ use (e.g., "food") was again observed but not significantly increased.

4. Final /p, m/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Practiced final /p/ and /m/ in CVC words during a turn-taking game.
- Child demonstrated occasional clear final consonants with visual and verbal cues, consistent with recent sessions.
- Overall, final consonant production appears to be stabilizing at an emerging level.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue at current levels for /k/ and /f/ practice, focusing on maintaining gains and gradually increasing sentence variety as tolerated.
- Keep final consonant work at the CVC word level with strong visual supports.
- Encourage caregiver to continue home practice with a small, manageable set of target words and sentences, emphasizing quality of productions over quantity.

Parent report:
Mom reported that she understands most of what he says, but others have a harder time. She notices he often leaves off the ends of words and says “tup” for “cup” and “tar” for “car.” No major changes since the evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned with some hesitation but separated from mom with reassurance. He was generally cooperative and curious, though he preferred to move quickly between toys. Needed intermittent redirection to stay with structured tasks but responded well to visual supports and turn-taking games.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted final consonants in simple CVC words (e.g., “cup, map, cat, sit, mop”) at the imitation level.
- Client frequently omitted final consonants or substituted a neutral vowel (“cu-” for “cup”).
- With maximal verbal cues (e.g., “stop your sound,” “close your lips at the end”) and tactile cues on his chin/hand-over-hand tapping, he was able to mark some final sounds, but accuracy was inconsistent and required slow pacing and repetition.

2. Initial /k/ vs /t/ contrast (fronting)
- Practiced initial /k/ in isolation and in simple syllables (e.g., “ku, ki, ka”) using visual cues (tongue “back sound”) and mirror.
- Client often produced /t/ for /k/ in imitation, even with modeling.
- A few accurate /k/ productions emerged when paired with a strong cough-like cue and exaggerated model, but he was not yet consistent.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Introduced “snake sound” /s/ in isolation with visual cue (finger for airflow) and mirror.
- Client was able to approximate a prolonged airflow in isolation with moderate verbal and gestural support, though he frequently added a vowel (“suh”).
- Attempted /s/ in CV syllables (e.g., “see, so, suh”), but productions often shifted to /d/ or /sh/; remained largely at isolation level today.

4. Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Observed spontaneous productions during play: mostly CV and CVCV reduplicated forms (e.g., “baba,” “mama,” “nana”), with fewer clear CVC words.
- Used simple picture routines to model CVCV (alternating) words (e.g., “puppy, baby”) and encouraged imitation; client could imitate the overall syllable pattern but individual sounds were often unclear.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue targeting final consonants in simple CVC words at the imitation level, using tapping and “stop your sound” cues.
- Continue establishing /k/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables before moving up to consistent word-level practice.
- Encourage parents to model slow, clear CVC words in daily routines (e.g., “cup, bed, hat”) without pressuring him to repeat; praise any attempts to mark the ending sound.

Parent report:
Mom shared that she has been trying to emphasize word endings at home and noticed he occasionally says “up” more clearly, but most words still sound the same. She feels his speech is about the same overall.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client separated easily today and went straight for the car toys. He was engaged when activities were play-based and brief, but he became silly when tasks were too repetitive. Responded well to visual schedules and choices between two activities.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Continued practice at the imitation level with picture cards and play (e.g., feeding animals “cup, ham, hat, map”).
- Client required frequent verbal reminders (“close your lips,” “put your tongue up at the end”) and hand-tapping cues.
- Some emerging attempts to mark the final sound were observed (e.g., “cu(p), ma(p)”), but endings were still often weak or omitted.

2. Initial /k/ in syllables and words
- Revisited /k/ in isolation and CV syllables with mirror and “back sound” explanation.
- Client continued to substitute /t/ for /k/ in many attempts, though a few more clear /k/ productions were noted compared to last session, especially when paired with a “cough” cue.
- Trialed a small number of CVC words (e.g., “car, cup”) in imitation; accuracy remained low and required maximal support.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Practiced /s/ in isolation using “snake sound” visual and airflow cues. Client produced a sustained /s/ more consistently today with moderate cueing.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “see, so, sa”), productions were mixed: some clear /s/ on initial trials, but often followed by a schwa or changed to /d/.
- Still primarily at syllable level; not yet ready for structured word-level practice.

4. Syllable structure (CVCV words)
- Used a farm play routine to elicit CVCV words (e.g., “piggy, puppy, baby”).
- Client imitated overall rhythm of multisyllabic words but tended to reduce or blur consonants.
- No notable changes in spontaneous syllable patterns compared to last session.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue current targets; skills appear relatively stable and still in early acquisition.
- Maintain focus on consistent final consonant marking and establishing clearer /k/ and /s/ in simple syllables.
- Home: Encourage slow models of CVC words and praise any attempts to add an ending sound; continue modeling “snake sound” with long /s/ during play (e.g., toy snakes, cars going “ssss”).

Parent report:
Mom reported a few new clearer words this week, including “cup” and “hot,” especially when she reminded him to “finish the word.” She feels family members understood him a little better at dinner.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client entered the room happily and followed the routine with minimal prompting. He sustained attention well for short table tasks when paired with motivating toys. Occasional restlessness, but he accepted breaks and returned to work with gentle prompts.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Practiced CVC words at the imitation level using picture cards and a “feed the monster” game (e.g., “cup, map, mat, ham, sit”).
- Notable improvement in his ability to mark final consonants when given a model and a simple cue (e.g., tapping the table at the end). Many productions were approximated but recognizable (e.g., “cu[p], ma[p]”).
- Accuracy and consistency increased compared to previous sessions, though he still needed prompts to slow down and avoid dropping endings.

2. Initial /k/ in syllables and CVC words
- Continued with /k/ in isolation and CV syllables, then moved into a small set of CVC words (e.g., “car, key, cow, cup”).
- With focused cueing (mirror, “tongue back,” “cough” trick), he produced several accurate /k/ sounds in initial position.
- He remained inconsistent and occasionally reverted to /t/, but he showed more successful attempts and some self-correction when cued.

3. Initial /s/ in CV syllables and emerging word level
- Practiced /s/ in CV syllables (e.g., “see, so, su, sa”) with visual and verbal cues.
- Accuracy in syllables improved; he could produce a clearer /s/ at the beginning with moderate support.
- Trialed a few simple words (e.g., “sun, sock”) at the imitation level. Productions were variable but a few recognizable /s/ initial words were achieved with cues.

4. Syllable shapes and simple phrases
- Observed more CVC attempts in spontaneous play (e.g., “bus,” “hot,” approximations for “cat”).
- Modeled 2–3 word carrier phrases (e.g., “my ___,” “big ___”) during toy play. Client imitated some short phrases, but sound accuracy within phrases dropped compared to single words.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build consistency for final consonants at the word level and strengthen emerging /k/ and /s/ productions.
- Begin to increase the set of CVC words where endings are marked more reliably.
- Home: Practice a small list of familiar CVC words (e.g., “cup, map, hat, hot”) using slow speech and gentle reminders to “finish the word”; keep practice short and playful.

Parent report:
Mom noted that he is starting to copy her more when she slows down words, and she can now sometimes hear the /t/ at the end of words like “hot” and “seat.” She still worries that unfamiliar listeners have difficulty understanding him.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was eager to participate and asked for preferred toys by name. He tolerated brief table-top tasks and transitioned between play and work with simple visual cues. Minimal avoidance behaviours today.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t, k/)
- Expanded CVC targets to include /k/ final (e.g., “back, book”) in addition to /p, m, t/.
- At the imitation level, he showed increasing consistency marking final /p, m, t/ with moderate cues; fewer complete omissions compared to earlier sessions.
- Final /k/ remained more challenging, with some productions approximated as /t/ or omitted, but he attempted the back sound when reminded.

2. Initial /k/ at word level
- Focused on a small set of initial /k/ words (e.g., “car, cow, key, cup”) in imitation.
- Demonstrated more frequent accurate /k/ productions at the start of words, especially in structured drills with mirror.
- Still required verbal prompts to keep the tongue back, but needed slightly fewer repetitions to achieve a correct production.

3. Initial /s/ in words and simple phrases
- Practiced initial /s/ words (e.g., “sun, sock, soup, seat”) at the imitation level.
- Accuracy was variable but improved compared to the prior week; he produced several clear /s/ initial words with moderate cues.
- Briefly introduced 2-word phrases with initial /s/ words (e.g., “sun up,” “sock on”). Within phrases, /s/ sometimes became less distinct, but he attempted the sound and could correct with support.

4. Short carrier phrases with target words
- Used simple carriers (e.g., “my ___,” “go ___”) to embed CVC targets in phrases.
- Client imitated some 2–3 word phrases with clearer final consonants, though endings were still more consistent in single words than in phrases.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue consolidating final consonant production, especially /k/ final, and strengthening initial /k/ and /s/ at the word level.
- Gradually increase practice of short phrases once word-level accuracy is more stable.
- Home: Encourage practice with picture cards or real objects for a small group of /k/ and /s/ words, using slow models and positive feedback for any clear attempts.

Parent report:
Mom reported that his words are “a bit clearer” this week, and she is hearing more ends of words without having to remind him every time. She also noticed he said “key” and “car” more distinctly while playing at home.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client entered the therapy room independently and engaged quickly with the chosen game. He maintained attention well with minimal redirection and followed visual rules (first work, then play). Overall participation was strong.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t, k/)
- Continued practice of CVC words at the imitation level and introduced more spontaneous productions during play.
- Marked improvement in consistency of final /p, m, t/; he often produced recognizable endings with only light verbal reminders.
- Final /k/ still required more support, but he achieved several accurate productions (e.g., “back, book”) when given a clear model and “back sound” cue.

2. Initial /k/ in words and early phrases
- Practiced initial /k/ words (e.g., “car, cow, cookie, key”) in imitation, then in simple 2-word phrases (e.g., “my car,” “big cow”).
- Accuracy for /k/ at the word level was noticeably better; he needed fewer cues to keep his tongue back and sometimes self-corrected when he produced /t/.
- In short phrases, /k/ remained mostly present but occasionally weakened; still, overall clarity was improved compared to previous sessions.

3. Initial /s/ at word level
- Targeted initial /s/ words (e.g., “sun, sock, soap, seat, soup”) primarily at the imitation level.
- He produced more consistent /s/ initial words with moderate cueing (e.g., “long snake sound” and mirror).
- Occasional substitutions to /d/ or /sh/ were noted, but he responded to cues and could often adjust on a second attempt.

4. Short phrases combining target sounds
- Used play-based routines (cars, kitchen set) to elicit 2–3 word phrases containing target words (e.g., “my cup,” “big sun,” “car up”).
- Client imitated several phrases with clearer final consonants and initial /k/, though accuracy still decreased somewhat compared to single words.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue strengthening consistency of final /k/ and initial /s/ at the word level, and gradually increase phrase-level practice for /k/ where accuracy is stronger.
- Home: Provide short, fun practice with a few target words each day (e.g., “cup, map, car, key, sun”), encouraging him to “finish the word” and praising any good attempts; avoid over-correcting to keep him motivated.

Parent report:
Mom stated that he is talking more and using short phrases like “my car” and “big truck.” She still notices he sometimes drops sounds when he talks fast, but she feels he is easier to understand than a few weeks ago.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was cheerful and talkative on arrival. He participated well in structured tasks and enjoyed turn-taking games. Needed occasional prompts to slow down his speech when excited but remained cooperative throughout.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t, k/)
- Practiced a larger set of CVC words in imitation and during play.
- Final /p, m, t/ were generally well-marked in imitation with only light cues; he occasionally omitted endings in spontaneous speech but could add them when reminded.
- Final /k/ showed gradual improvement; he produced clearer endings in words like “back” and “book” when paced slowly, though consistency was still emerging.

2. Initial /k/ at word and phrase level
- Continued with initial /k/ words and short phrases (e.g., “my car,” “go car,” “key please”).
- Word-level /k/ was fairly consistent with moderate cues; he needed reminders to use his “back sound” but required fewer repetitions to get a correct production.
- In phrases, /k/ was present in many attempts but sometimes softened or changed to /t/ when he rushed.

3. Initial /s/ at word level and limited phrases
- Practiced initial /s/ words (e.g., “sun, sock, sit, soup”) with visual and verbal cues.
- Accuracy showed slight improvement; he could maintain a clearer /s/ at the beginning of several words, though not yet reliably across the full set.
- Trialed a few short phrases with /s/ words (e.g., “sun up,” “sock on”); within phrases, he often needed a reminder to use his snake sound.

4. Short phrases with mixed targets
- Used play-based scenarios to elicit 2–3 word phrases containing target words (e.g., “big cup,” “my book,” “see car”).
- Client imitated multiple phrases and occasionally produced them spontaneously, but sound accuracy within phrases remained less consistent than in isolation or single words.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue consolidating gains at the word level and gradually increase phrase-level practice, especially for initial /k/ and final consonants.
- Home: Encourage slower speech in natural routines (e.g., mealtimes, bath) by modeling short phrases and pausing for him to repeat; gently remind him to "finish the word" without overemphasis.

Parent report:
Mom reported that he is starting to correct himself sometimes, for example saying “ca—car” after she looks at him. She is hearing more clear words like “book,” “cup,” and “car” in everyday routines.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned easily and was very engaged in today’s activities. He followed directions well and showed good persistence with slightly more challenging tasks. Enjoyed being the “teacher” and giving the clinician a turn.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t, k/)
- Practiced final consonants at the word level with imitation and then in simple games that encouraged more independent productions.
- For /p, m, t/, he produced many clear endings with minimal verbal cues and occasional spontaneous accuracy during play.
- Final /k/ remained somewhat less consistent but showed better accuracy than previous weeks, particularly when he was reminded to slow down.

2. Initial /k/ in words and short phrases
- Targeted a variety of initial /k/ words (e.g., “car, cow, cookie, key, cat”) in imitation and short phrases (e.g., “my car,” “see cat,” “cookie please”).
- He produced initial /k/ correctly in many words with only light support and sometimes self-corrected from /t/ to /k/ after a prompt.
- In short phrases, /k/ was often present and recognizable, though clarity decreased slightly when he spoke quickly.

3. Initial /s/ in words and early phrases
- Continued practice with initial /s/ words (e.g., “sun, sock, soup, seat, soap”) using visual and verbal cues.
- He demonstrated more consistent /s/ productions in a subset of words, though accuracy still varied across the full list.
- Introduced additional 2-word phrases with /s/ words (e.g., “sun up,” “see soup”); he could imitate these with moderate cueing but rarely produced /s/ independently.

4. Short carrier phrases with multiple targets
- Used carrier phrases (e.g., “I see __,” “my __,” “big __”) to embed CVC and /k/ words.
- Client imitated several 2–3 word phrases with recognizable target sounds, particularly for /k/ and final /p, t/.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen consistency and independence at the word level for /s/ and final /k/, while increasing phrase-level practice for sounds that are more stable (/k/ initial, final /p, t/).
- Home: Encourage short, repeated phrases using familiar targets (e.g., “my car,” “big cup,” “see sun”), praising any self-corrections or clear endings.

Parent report:
Mom shared that he is talking in more 3–4 word phrases at home (e.g., “I see car,” “my big book”). She feels his words are clearer, though he still drops sounds when excited or tired.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was enthusiastic and chatty. He engaged well in both table and floor activities, and enjoyed “fixing” the clinician’s silly mistakes. Needed mild reminders to take turns and listen, but overall participation was strong.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words and phrases
- Practiced final /p, m, t, k/ in CVC words at the imitation and spontaneous levels within structured games.
- He produced many CVC words with clear final consonants in imitation and often carried this over into short phrases (e.g., “big cup,” “my map”) when cued to slow down.
- Occasional omissions were still observed in more rapid speech, but overall stability was maintained from last session.

2. Initial /k/ in phrases and short sentences
- Focused on initial /k/ in 2–3 word phrases (e.g., “my car go,” “see cow,” “cookie please”) and brief sentence-like structures.
- /k/ remained relatively strong at this level; he produced many accurate /k/ sounds with light verbal reminders, though he still occasionally fronted to /t/ when rushing.

3. Initial /s/ at word and phrase level
- Continued work on initial /s/ words and 2-word phrases (e.g., “see sun,” “sock on,” “sit down”).
- Accuracy appeared similar to last week: some words produced clearly with cues, while others were still substituted or reduced.
- He responded to visual cues (snake gesture) but was not yet consistently independent with /s/.

4. Short functional phrases with mixed targets
- Used play-based routines (farm, cars) to elicit 3–4 word phrases (e.g., “I see big car,” “my book on top”).
- Client imitated many of these phrases; sound accuracy was generally better in structured tasks than in his more spontaneous remarks.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain current targets, focusing on consolidating gains in final consonants and initial /k/ in phrases, and continuing to support emerging /s/ accuracy.
- Home: Model and encourage short phrases using familiar targets, especially in daily routines (e.g., “my cup please,” “see sun”), and gently cue him to slow down if endings are dropped.

Parent report:
Mom reported no major changes since last week. She feels he is still easier to understand than before therapy, but she continues to hear some dropped sounds in longer sentences.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client came in happily and was eager to show his new toy car. He participated well in structured and play-based tasks. Some mild silliness when tasks became repetitive, but he responded to brief movement breaks.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants in CVC words and short phrases
- Continued practice of final /p, m, t, k/ within CVC words and 2–3 word phrases.
- Performance remained similar to last session: good accuracy for final /p, m, t/ with light cues, and improving but still variable final /k/.
- Endings were more likely to be omitted when he spoke quickly or in longer utterances.

2. Initial /k/ in phrases
- Targeted initial /k/ within short phrases and simple sentence frames (e.g., “I see car,” “my cat go,” “cow is big”).

- Practiced initial /s/ words and 2-word phrases using visual cues and minimal pair contrasts (e.g., “see/tea,” “sip/tip”).
- Accuracy remained somewhat inconsistent; some clear /s/ productions were observed, but substitutions and distortions were still frequent.
- He showed interest in listening to the differences but needed ongoing support to produce /s/ reliably.

4. Functional phrases and conversation
- Encouraged use of target words within short conversational exchanges (e.g., asking for toys, commenting on play).
- Client produced several 3–4 word utterances, with sound accuracy similar to structured tasks for easier targets and reduced accuracy for newer sounds like /s/.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue with current targets to allow further consolidation, particularly for final /k/ and initial /s/.
- Home: Keep practicing short, predictable phrases (e.g., “I see car,” “big cup,” “sun up”), reinforcing clear endings and "back sound" /k/; avoid pressuring for perfect /s/ but praise any good "snake sound" attempts.

Goals / session focus:
Goal 1: Initial /s/ at word level (imitation)

- Practiced /f/ in CV syllables ("fa, fee, foo") and simple words (e.g., four, fish, fun) using tactile cues to bite the lip and blow air.

- Probed final consonant use in high-interest CVC words (e.g., map, mop, mat, mom) in imitation.

- Observed and elicited a variety of syllable shapes during play (e.g., "baby, bunny, teddy").
- CV and reduplicated CVCV forms (e.g., "mama, dada") were produced readily; alternating CVCV (e.g., "bunny") were sometimes simplified.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue targeting initial /s/ and /f/ at the imitated word level with heavy visual and tactile cueing.
- Maintain focus on marking final consonants in simple CVC words using simultaneous productions and visual prompts.
- Encourage parent to model clear, slightly slowed speech at home and emphasize final sounds in familiar words (e.g., "up," "cup") without pressuring the child to repeat.

- Continued structured spontaneous practice of /s/ in naming tasks and brief conversational exchanges.
- Performance remained comparable to previous week: many correct /s/ productions in structured tasks, with a tendency to revert to less accurate patterns when excited or when talking in longer stretches.
- Required occasional verbal reminders ("snake sound") to maintain accuracy.

Goal 2: Initial /f/ in words and short phrases
- Practiced /f/ within play (feeding animals, counting "four" and "five" items) and short phrases.
- Accuracy at the word and short phrase level was stable; he generally produced /f/ well in structured contexts but still needed support when moving into more spontaneous conversation.

Goal 3: Final consonant production in CVC words (p, t, m) at word and phrase level
- Used picture cards and simple phrases (e.g., "big map," "red hat," "mom's cup") to practice final consonant marking.
- He maintained similar levels of accuracy compared to the last session, with good success for final /p/ and /t/ in imitation and cued phrases, and more variable success for final /m/.
- No notable change in the type or amount of cueing required.

Goal 4: /s/ blends at the imitated word level
- Practiced a small set of /s/ blends (spoon, star, stop, snow, slide) in direct imitation.
- Client continued to need maximal cues to include both consonants. Some isolated accurate productions occurred, but consistency was limited.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue current focus on consolidating independent /s/ and /f/ productions and reinforcing final consonants in functional words.
- Parent encouraged to create simple phrase practice at home (e.g., "big sun," "more food") to help bridge from single words to short phrases.
- Next session: maintain similar targets and monitor for any shifts in independence or readiness to expand /s/ blends and phrase-level final consonants.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Parent reported that the child is "chatty" at home and that they are understanding him better in short sentences, especially when he slows down.
- They continue to hear clearer /s/ and /f/ in many of his practiced words.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Walked into the therapy room independently and quickly engaged with the clinician.
- Demonstrated good attention and cooperation across activities, with only brief moments of silliness that were easily redirected.

Goals / session focus:
Goal 1: Initial /s/ in words, short phrases, and brief conversation

Goal 2: Initial /f/ in words and short phrases
- Continued /f/ practice in play-based tasks (e.g., pretend cooking and feeding games) with words such as food, fish, fork, and four.
- Performance was similar to prior sessions; he produced /f/ clearly in most structured attempts but still required support to maintain accuracy when speaking more spontaneously.

Goal 3: Final consonant production in CVC words (p, t, m) at word and phrase level
- Practiced final consonants using a mix of picture cards and short phrases ("big map," "hot soup," "mom's cup").
- Accuracy for final /p/ and /t/ in imitation and cued phrases remained stable. Final /m/ continued to be variable but showed some correct productions in familiar words.
- Overall, skills appear to be consolidating at this level.

Goal 4: /s/ blends at the imitated word level
- Revisited /s/ blends (spoon, star, stop, slide) with direct imitation and visual cues.
- Client produced a few clearer blends, though reduction to single consonants was still common. Level of cueing required remained high.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue working at the current levels to solidify consistency and support carryover into longer phrases and conversation.
- Parent encouraged to model slightly slower speech and to repeat child’s utterances with clear /s/, /f/, and final consonants, without pressuring him to imitate every time.
- Next session: maintain similar targets and continue monitoring for generalization across contexts.

Goals / session focus:

Session 1

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother attended with client. She reported that speech "sounds a bit unclear" to unfamiliar listeners but family usually understands him.
- No major changes since referral. Mom notices he often leaves off the ends of words (e.g., "pi" for "pig").

Behaviour/Engagement:
- 4-year-old boy, transitioned to therapy room with brief hesitation, then separated from mom without difficulty.
- Engaged well with toy farm and cars; needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to speech tasks.
- Participated in imitation tasks when activities were play-based and visually supported.

Goals/Intervention Focus:
1. Establish awareness of final consonants in CVC words (e.g., /p, m, t/)
   - Targeted through picture naming and play (e.g., "map," "cup," "ham," "cat").
   - In imitation, client often omitted final consonants or added a vowel (e.g., "ca-tuh").
   - With simultaneous production and visual cue of “closing the word,” he produced final /p, m, t/ accurately in a few trials but not yet consistent.

2. Initial /k/ vs /t/ (fronting)
   - Probed in isolation and simple CV syllables ("kuh," "kee," "koo") using tongue-back cues and visuals.
   - Frequently substituted /t/ for /k/ at word level (e.g., "tar" for "car").
   - Able to approximate /k/ in isolation with maximal verbal and visual cues and hand cue to “back sound” in about half of attempts.

3. Initial /s/ in simple words
   - Screened at word level during play ("sun," "sock," "soap," "sit").
   - Productions were variable: substitutions included /d/ and /z/, occasional omission of consonant.
   - Client watched clinician’s mouth but needed frequent reminders to keep tongue behind teeth; no consistent independent productions yet.

4. Overall speech sound inventory / baseline
   - Informal play-based sampling suggested reduced intelligibility at phrase level, especially for unfamiliar listener.
   - Patterns noted: final consonant deletion, stopping of some fricatives, and fronting of velars.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue weekly sessions focusing on final consonant production in simple CVC words and establishing a consistent /k/ in isolation and CV syllables.
- Encourage parent to emphasize final sounds in everyday words (e.g., “cuP,” “caT”) using slow, clear models without asking child to repeat every time.
- Next session: begin structured practice for final /p, m, t/ at imitated word level and continue shaping /k/ in isolation.

Session 2

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother reported no big changes since last week. She notices he sometimes corrects himself when she repeats a word with a strong final sound.
- Family has been trying to slow down their own speech and emphasize word endings as discussed.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Smooth transition into therapy room; greeted clinician spontaneously.
- Remained seated at the table for short activities, then preferred floor-based play. Responded well to alternating between structured tasks and play breaks.
- Good overall participation with minimal frustration; accepted cues and feedback.

Goals/Intervention Focus:
1. Final consonants /p, m, t/ in CVC words (imitation)
   - Practiced with picture cards and toy food ("cup," "cap," "ham," "map," "cat," "hat").
   - With simultaneous production and visual cue (tapping for the last sound), he produced clearer final consonants more frequently than last session.
   - Still tended to add a vowel or drop the final consonant without support; accuracy improved when clinician slowed the word and drew attention to the “last sound.”

2. /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
   - Continued tongue-back practice using mirror, picture of tongue position, and “cough sound” cue.
   - Achieved several good /k/ sounds in isolation with maximal verbal and visual cues.
   - CV syllables ("koo," "kay," "kee") were emerging; often reverted to /t/ at the start, but a few approximations of /k/ at the syllable level were observed with heavy support.

3. Initial /s/ in simple words (imitated)
   - Targeted limited set of words ("sun," "sock," "soap") at the imitation level.
   - Client continued to show variable productions; some close approximations of /s/ when given cue to “make the long snake sound” and keep teeth together.
   - Still requires frequent modeling and verbal cueing; not yet consistent at word level.

4. Functional phrases for clarity
   - During play, clinician modeled short 2–3 word phrases with emphasized final sounds ("big cup," "red hat").
   - Child imitated several short phrases but often reduced endings; some attempts to self-correct when clinician repeated with emphasis.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue at current levels: imitated CVC words for final /p, m, t/ and /k/ in isolation/CV.
- Encourage caregiver to play simple “listening games” at home: noticing when words end with a “p” or “t” sound.
- Next session: build consistency for final /p, m, t/ and continue shaping /k/ toward more reliable CV productions.

Session 3

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother reported he is starting to "copy" her clearer models more often, especially with words like "cup" and "cat."
- She notices some words sound "stronger" at the end, though he is not consistent yet.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Entered room easily and chose preferred car track toy as a motivator.
- Attended well to structured tasks when integrated into turn-taking games; required minimal redirection.
- Demonstrated good persistence with challenging sounds when given positive reinforcement.

Goals/Intervention Focus:
1. Final consonants /p, m, t/ in CVC words (imitation → cued independent)
   - Practiced with picture cards and a simple board game.
   - With a verbal cue only (no simultaneous production), client produced clearer final /p, m, t/ in many trials.
   - Emerging ability to produce final consonants after a model and then on a second trial with reduced cues; still occasional omissions, but overall accuracy and consistency notably improved from prior session.

2. /k/ in isolation and CV syllables (progressing)
   - Used mirror work and “cough sound” cue followed by shaping into “car,” “key,” “cow.”
   - Able to produce /k/ in isolation with moderate cues more consistently.
   - In CV syllables, produced initial /k/ correctly or closely approximated in a higher proportion of attempts; occasional /t/ substitutions persist but fewer than last session.

3. Initial /k/ in single words (imitated)
   - Trialed simple words ("car," "key," "cow") at the imitated word level.
   - Needed verbal reminders to “use the back sound”; showed several correct or near-correct productions when focused.
   - This represents a step up from prior sessions, where /k/ was mostly limited to isolation.

4. Initial /s/ in simple words (imitated)
   - Revisited small set of words ("sun," "sock," "soap").
   - Child produced more consistent initial fricative-like sounds with cue to “keep tongue behind teeth and blow slowly.”
   - Some substitutions remain, but more attempts at a true /s/ and better differentiation from /d/.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to consolidate final consonants at the imitated word level and begin to check for carryover into short phrases (e.g., "red cup").
- Increase practice of /k/ at the imitated word level with visual cues.
- Home: parent to pick 3–4 “practice words” (e.g., cup, cat, map) and model slowly, encouraging child to try once or twice without pressure.
- Next session: expand /k/ word set and monitor for readiness to try short carrier phrases with strong final consonants.

Session 4

Behaviour/Engagement:

- Remained engaged for most of the session with brief movement breaks.
- Showed increased willingness to look in the mirror and watch articulatory cues.

Goals/Intervention Focus:
1. Final consonants /p, m, t/ in CVC words (word → short phrase level)
   - Reviewed imitated CVC words, then moved into short, structured phrases (e.g., "red cup," "big map," "my cat").
   - At word level, client produced final /p, m, t/ with relatively good consistency when given a light verbal reminder.
   - In short phrases, some final consonants were dropped again, but with a quick cue to “finish the word,” he was often able to repair the production.

2. /k/ initial in words (imitation)
   - Practiced "car," "key," "cow," "cup" using picture cards and car play.
   - Demonstrated more consistent use of a back-of-the-tongue sound when cued; fewer /t/ substitutions than previous sessions.
   - Still requires moderate visual/verbal cues and slower rate, but accuracy at the imitated word level is improving.

3. Initial /s/ in words (imitation; emerging phrases)
   - Continued with "sun," "sock," "soap," and introduced "sit" in a game context.
   - Produced more recognizable /s/ sounds at the start of words with cues to “keep teeth closed” and “long sound.”
   - Trialed simple phrase "bye sun" and "see sock" with mixed accuracy; needed modeling and reminders but attempted to maintain the /s/.

4. Functional intelligibility in play
   - In spontaneous play, client used many 2–4 word utterances; speech remained variably intelligible, but some words with final consonants and /k/ appeared more clearly when they had just been practiced.
   - Occasional self-corrections observed after clinician repeated the word with emphasis.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen final consonant production in both single words and short carrier phrases.
- Maintain focus on /k/ initial words at the imitated level; consider expanding to a few new /k/ words as accuracy stabilizes.
- Home: parent to use simple phrases ("big cup," "my cat") and gently highlight the last sound.
- Next session: continue same goals, watching for increasing independence before moving to more spontaneous phrase-level use.

4. Summary of current speech profile

Plan/Recommendations:

- Next block: consider maintaining current targets while gradually increasing phrase/sentence complexity for well-established words and exploring additional sound patterns as appropriate.

Parent report:
Mother attended today and reported that she and other family members continue to have difficulty understanding child’s speech, especially with longer words and when he is excited. She noted that he is starting to notice when others do not understand him and will sometimes repeat louder instead of changing his sounds.

Behaviour/engagement:
Child transitioned into the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from mother without tears. He was curious about the toys and participated best in play-based activities. Attention was variable; needed several gentle redirections back to speech tasks but remained generally cooperative.

Goals / Observations:
1. Establish production of /k/ in isolation and simple syllables (CV, VC)
- Baseline probe completed. Child frequently substituted /t/ for /k/ in both play and structured tasks (e.g., "tar" for "car").
- In isolation, he was inconsistently able to produce a backed sound approximating /k/ with maximal verbal and visual cues (e.g., “tongue up and back,” use of mirror). Accuracy was low and required repeated modeling.
- CV and VC syllables (e.g., "ku," "ik"): productions were mostly /t/ or omitted. Occasional close approximations when clinician used exaggerated mouth model and slowed rate.

2. Establish production of /f/ in isolation
- Baseline indicated frequent stopping of /f/ to /p/ in both initial and final positions.
- In isolation trials, child was able to imitate a weak /f/ sound in a few attempts with direct modeling, mirror, and “bite your lip, blow” instruction, but often reverted to /p/ or silent blowing.

3. Observe overall consonant accuracy in simple CVC words
- Informal play-based sample revealed patterns of fronting (/k, g/→/t, d/) and stopping of fricatives (/s, f/→/t, p/). Final consonants were sometimes omitted in spontaneous speech.
- Intelligibility in familiar context (with clinician after some exposure) was judged to be fair; required frequent clarification requests.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to focus on establishing /k/ and /f/ in isolation with high levels of visual and verbal cueing.
- Introduce simple CV syllables for /k/ as tolerated.
- Encourage caregiver to model slow, clear speech at home and emphasize sounds in fun routines (e.g., “car,” “go,” “off”) without pressuring for imitation.

- With moderate cues, he produced many accurate CVC words; in some familiar items (e.g., “cup, cat, map”), he required only a light verbal reminder or none at all, indicating readiness to begin fading supports.

2) Initial /k/ in words and short carrier phrases
- Practiced initial /k/ words (“car, key, cow, cookie”) and introduced short carrier phrases (e.g., “my car,” “big cow”) at the imitated level.
- Child maintained improved /k/ accuracy at word level with less cueing and was able to produce several correct /k/ sounds within short phrases when modeled.
- Some reversion to /t/ was observed when phrases became longer, but he responded to brief reminders to “use your back sound.”

3) Initial /s/ at word level
- Continued work on /s/ in words (“sun, soap, sock, soup”) using a “snake sound” visual and mirror.
- Child produced a greater proportion of accurate /s/ in imitation, although substitutions (/d/, /th/) still occurred.
- He began to accept fewer tactile cues and responded better to simple verbal prompts and visual supports, showing moderate improvement in consistency.

4) Early phrase-level practice with final consonants
- Introduced short 2–3 word phrases that combined final consonants with high-interest nouns (e.g., “big cup,” “hot soup”) in imitation.
- Child was able to mark some final sounds within these phrases when provided with a clear model and slowed rate, though accuracy was lower than at single-word level.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to consolidate CVC final consonant accuracy; if consistency remains high, gradually increase the number of phrase-level trials next session.
- Maintain initial /k/ practice in short carrier phrases and begin to increase variety of /k/ words.
- Continue structured /s/ word practice; may trial limited /s/ blends in future once single /s/ is more stable.
- Home practice: caregiver to model and practice 2-word phrases with final consonants (e.g., “big cup,” “red hat”) during daily routines, focusing on slow, clear speech.
